name: inves7
headline: The global financial system is increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few asset management giants whose decisions shape capital flows, market sentiment, and long-term investment trends worldwide.
content: The global financial system is increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few asset management giants whose decisions shape capital flows, market sentiment, and long-term investment trends worldwide. Today, a small group of institutions manages an extraordinary share of global wealth, influencing equities, bonds, infrastructure projects, private markets, and even commodity demand. Among the most dominant players: â€¢ BlackRock â€” approx. $13.5T AUM The largest asset manager in the world, with a powerful footprint across ETFs, institutional mandates, and risk management technology. Its scale gives it structural influence over global asset allocation. â€¢ Vanguard â€” approx. $11.6T AUM A pioneer of passive investing, driving the global expansion of low-cost index funds and reshaping how millions of investors access markets. â€¢ Fidelity Investments â€” approx. $6.8T AUM A major force in active management, retirement solutions, and brokerage services, with strong positioning across both retail and institutional segments. â€¢ UBS â€” approx. $6.6T AUM One of the strongest global wealth management platforms, with deep penetration in Europe, Asia, and high-net-worth advisory. â€¢ State Street â€” approx. $5.45T AUM A cornerstone of institutional asset servicing and ETF management, playing a critical role in market infrastructure. â€¢ JPMorganChase Asset Management â€” approx. $4.6T AUM A global powerhouse combining active strategies, alternatives, and institutional distribution. â€¢ Goldman Sachs Asset Management â€” approx. $3.45T AUM Strong positioning in alternatives, private markets, and high-end institutional mandates. â€¢ Capital Group â€” approx. $3T AUM One of the oldest and most respected active managers, with a long-term investment philosophy. These firms are not just managing capital â€” they are shaping global economic direction. Their allocation decisions impact liquidity, valuations, capital access for companies, and the evolution of entire sectors. Understanding where capital concentrates is essential to understanding where markets move next. ğŸ’ INVEST Magazine â€” Coming Soon! Stay ahead of global markets with smart insights, strategy, and analysis from top financial thinkers. Get your free access to the next issue of INVEST Magazine and discover how investors worldwide are navigating markets. ğŸ‘‰ Subscribe now on LinkedIn: https://lnkd.in/dYywATTR ğŸ“ˆ INVEST â€” Knowledge is your best investment. Sources: Fiscal.ai , public disclosures from major asset managers #Investing #AssetManagement #WealthManagement #GlobalFinance #CapitalMarkets #InstitutionalInvestors #INVEST #Inves7

name: testerops
headline: Career advice is in no short supply. In fact, you could probably spend the duration of your working life simply reading through the tips and advice already online.
content: Career advice is in no short supply . In fact, you could probably spend the duration of your working life simply reading through the tips and advice already online. But as in all areas of life, the more common something is, generally speaking, the lower its value. Many oft repeated truisms are more about wish fulfillment than reality (sorry peddlers of endless, uncritical "follow your passion!" posts ). Plus, tips that everyone and their mother (and their college career counselor) knows are unlikely to give you an edge over the competition. So what are the true hidden gems of career advice, the truths that few people are willing to say out loud that can actually transform a mediocre career into a rockstar one? That's what a someone on question-and-answer site Quora wanted to know recently, asking: " What are a few unique pieces of career advice that nobody ever mentions ?" The community responded with plenty of uncommon, thought-provoking advice. Doing Your Job Well Is Not Enough Being excellent at your job is a surefire way to get ahead, right? Nope, say several responders, including Victor Wong, CEO of PaperG. "Most people assume just doing their current assigned job well is enough--so many associates at law firms think doing all the paperwork and litigation properly is the road to partnership, and many PR account executives think that getting a few articles written about their clients will earn them a promotion," he writes, but "becoming a principal, partner, or senior executive with P&L-level responsibility requires a completely separate set of skills from entry and mid-level jobs." How do you make that leap? "To make the big jump to the next level, they're really being benchmarked on their ability to deliver future value to the firm in ways that are not taught or explained to them: chiefly how much business are they are able to bring in," he asserts. "People who can think of what to do and deliver are the ones who ultimately are more likely to get promoted to the top levels." Another anonymous poster agrees: "You don't become a star doing your job. You become a star making things happen." Who You Work For Is Hugely Important We all wish we lived in a world where who you know matters less than what you can do, but that's often not reality, and not always for unhealthy reasons. Knowing the best in the business often means you've worked with the best, and people rightly admire that. "You don't have to be passionate about the product you are selling. You don't have to be in the most glamorous industry. You don't have to work for the company with the best 'brand' identity or reputation in your chosen field," insists Jeremy Boudinet, director of marketing for startup Ambition. What does matter is who you've worked with. "Few things are as valuable as going and working for somebody that is going to want to teach you anything and everything they know. You'll experience tremendous personal and professional growth if you have the best person mentoring you ," he says, so "figure out where the absolute best person to work for would be, and go work for them." ... So Is Where You Work Just like who you work for can deeply affect the fate of your career, where you work also has a massive impact. Just saying, 'I want to work in software or sales,' isn't enough. Nor, as Boudinet point out, is it enough just to fill your resume with impressive company names. Your destiny is influenced greatly by the destiny of the particular organization that employs you. Don't take a job with just any old company because it's in the right sector or impresses your friends. "Your career is a boat and it is at the mercy of tides. No matter how talented you are it's a lot harder to break out in a sluggish situation/hierarchy/economy than a go-go environment. Even if you're a superstar at Sluggish Co., your upside trajectory (more often than not) is fractional to what an average/below average employee achieves at Rocket Ship Co," says an anonymous poster with the most up-voted answer. Being Seen as Super Busy Isn't Always a Good Thing Think high achievers work endless hours and are continuously busy ? Think again, writes Mira Zaslove, director of international sales and trading at FabExchange. "Ironically the busier you appear, often the less you will move up. I've seen smart and dedicated employees fail to get promoted, because they have taken on too much, are working too hard, and appeared too frazzled," she reports. "If you appear stressed, people will think you aren't prepared to take on more, and you'll miss opportunities for new and innovative projects." Take a Tour When plotting your first (or next) big career move, many of us think very abstractly, musing in solitude or in front of Google about the joys of our supposed dream jobs. But the truth is you can't decide on a career without seeing the day-to-day reality of where and how you work --the concrete truth rather than the imagined reality. Don't make decisions without actually going and seeing for yourself. Alek Mirkovich, founder of campayn.com, once thought becoming an air traffic controller was a great idea, but then he took a tour of where he would actually be working. "Every single guy was BALD! Playing around with a simulator is fun but apparently the real thing is stressful. Within 30 seconds I knew I wasn't going to be signing up for this!" he remembers. Don't Hide Your Failures Failures are seen less as a signal of incompetence and more as a sign that you're willing to take a risk and innovate, according to Zaslove. "Your team will respect you and your career will accelerate if people understand what you are doing and that you are taking risks. Most people do not view someone as credible if they are giving advice and recommendations, but not walking the walk," she claims. "If you show that you are willing to take risks, and publicly falter, your team will feel confident taking risks too. Lead by example." Execution Matters More Than Plans or Advice Many people are looking for the magic recipe of how to make their career take off, but many of the responders agree that there are some serious limits to what other people can tell you. "Advice (like ideas) is not in short supply, there is plenty of it going around," writes coach Darren Beattie, for instance. "It's not really the advice in the long run that matters, it's the execution of the advice by the person being advised. The greatest advice ever in the history of the human race is absolutely useless if you act/execute on none of it." Or to put it another way, there's no real roadmap that you can blindly follow . The trick is figuring out what to apply and what to ignore for your own personal situation. That same popular anonymous responder sums this idea up well: "Career tracks and meritocracies don't exist: Your career is not a linear, clearly defined trajectory." What less well known bit of career wisdom would you add to this list?

name: testerops
headline: The 8th Annual Crunchies Awards, hosted by TechCrunch kicked off at Davies Symphony Hall yesterday night. The Crunchies Awards ,hosted by TechCrunch and Venture Beat recognizes and celebrates the most compelling start ups, internet and technological innovations all over the year.
content: The 8th Annual Crunchies Awards, hosted by TechCrunch kicked off at Davies Symphony Hall yesterday night. The Crunchies Awards ,hosted by TechCrunch and Venture Beat recognizes and celebrates the most compelling start ups, internet and technological innovations all over the year. The Awards brought a range of start-ups and innovations round the year to the front of the online tech community. This year Slack seemed to be the major winner, as it was nominated in at least 4 different categories ( Fastest Rising Start-Up , Best Enterprise Start-Up , Founder of The Year , Best New Start-Up of The Year ). It ended up winning the award for the Founder of The Year with Stewart Butterfield , Eric Coestello , Carl Henderson and Sergei Mourachov winning this award. Rising and controversial start-up Yik Yak beat competition from Slack and Reddit , to win the Fastest Rising Start-Up of The Year , while the Airbnb design team brought laurels to the company by winning the Best Design segment. On international front, popular messaging app Line , trounced competitors like Spotify , Kik to take home the Best International Start-Up . On technology and hardware front, Occulus VR won the Best Hardware Start-Up , while Best Technology Achievement went to Stella-Solar Powered Car, which beat competition from Apple Pay and Rosettaâ€™s Comet Landing. On personal front, Jim Goetz of Sequioa Capital won the Venture Capitalist of the Year award, while Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff won the CEO of the Year award. Complete List of Award Winners : Best Technology Achievement Winner : Stella Solar-Powered Car Best On-Demand Service Winner : Hotel Tonight Best E-Commerce Application Winner : Casper Best Mobile Application Winner : Storehouse Fastest-Rising Startup Winner : Yik Yak Best Health Startup Winner : Theranos Best Design Winner: Airbnb Best Bootstrapped Startup Winner: Meadow Best Enterprise Startup Winner: CloudFlare Best International Startup Winner: Line Best Education Startup Winner: ClassDojo Best Hardware Startup Winner: Oculus VR Canâ€™t Stop, Wonâ€™t Stop Winner: Kim Kardashian: Hollywood Biggest Social Impact Winner: Twitter Angel of the Year Winner: Kickstarter Backers of Oculus VR VC of the Year Winner: Jim Goetz (Sequoia Capital) Founder of the Year Winner: Stewart Butterfield, Eric Costello, Cal Henderson and Serguei Mourachov (Slack) CEO of the Year Winner: Marc Benioff (Salesforce.com) Best New Startup of 2014 Winner: Product Hunt Best Overall Startup of 2014 Winner: Uber For a more detailed list of all award winners along with the runner-ups and finalists, head over to TechCrunchâ€™s page .

name: shubham-kumar-mittal-674a89122
headline: We used to measure time in BC & AD.
content: We used to measure time in BC & AD. Now it feels like life is split into BI & AI - Before Inflation & After Inflation. Somewhere after 2020, the baseline shifted. Not dramatically. Quietly. Permanently. Here are 10 things that didnâ€™t just get expensive. They got redefined. 1. Coffee meetings â†’ Financial decisions Catching up over coffee used to be casual. Now two cappuccinos and a dessert cross â‚¹900. The conversation is still light. The bill isnâ€™t. 2. Weddings â†’ Multi-day productions What was once a family function is now a staged event. Pre-shoots. Entry concepts. Hashtags. Guest experience teams. The emotional value is real. The financial escalation is unreal. 3. Kidsâ€™ schooling â†’ Corporate pricing logic Annual fees. Activity fees. Tech fees. International exposure fees. Education didnâ€™t just inflate. It repositioned itself as a premium service. 4. Eating healthy â†’ Paying a premium for basics Cold-pressed oils. Organic vegetables. Farm milk. A simple shift toward â€œclean eatingâ€ quietly doubles the grocery bill. 5. Convenience â†’ Subscription traps Music. Cloud storage. Fitness apps. Meditation apps. AI tools. Individually small. Collectively significant. Convenience now compounds monthly. 6. Moving homes â†’ A capital event Security deposits. Brokerage. Interiors. Appliances. Curtains. Moving isnâ€™t a logistical exercise anymore. Itâ€™s a financial project. 7. Gyms â†’ Lifestyle clubs What was â‚¹12k per year is now â‚¹45k â€” with juice bars, recovery zones, and â€œcommunity.â€ Fitness became an ecosystem. Pricing followed. 8. Work essentials â†’ Personal expenses Better chair. Better desk. Better mic. Better lighting. Work from home quietly shifted infrastructure costs from companies to individuals. 9. Travel mindset â†’ Travel justification Earlier: â€œLetâ€™s go somewhere.â€ Now: â€œIs it worth the cost?â€ The emotional spontaneity lost to financial calculation. 10. The definition of â€œnormalâ€ â†’ Completely rewritten â‚¹50k salary once meant stability. â‚¹2 lakh rent once meant luxury. â‚¹500 dinners once meant indulgence. Today, theyâ€™re part of ordinary conversations. Nothing feels shocking in isolation. Thatâ€™s the shift. It didnâ€™t happen in headlines. It happened in habits. We didnâ€™t suddenly start living luxuriously. We just slowly started paying luxury prices for normal lives.

name: debashishghosh1
headline: First things first, this is NOT a list of Top 4 events of 2017. If anything, unfortunately, 2017 could well be remembered as the year of deadly hurricanes.
content: First things first, this is NOT a list of Top 4 events of 2017. If anything, unfortunately, 2017 could well be remembered as the year of deadly hurricanes. Hurricanes Maria, Jose, Harvey and Irma caused unimaginable human tragedy last year. Besides, North Korea and Donald Trump hit the headlines almost every day. Rohingya crisis, Robert Mugabe, Fall of Mosul, Las Vegas mass shootingâ€¦.the list could go on. In this list, I have picked up four events from 2017 that could potentially have far-reaching impact in years to come â€“ in the fields of finance , economy and corporate governance only . I have heavily read, researched and borrowed opinions from many â€œTop 10â€ listings, expertsâ€™ views, and white papers. In a way, this is a â€œlist of listsâ€. And yes, these are not in any particular order. The Paradise Papers leak In November, German newspaper the SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung released millions of leaked documents relating to offshore investments of about 120000 individuals and corporations. Most of these documents originated from the Bermuda-based law firm Appleby, which confirmed that it had been targeted by a cyberattack in 2016. The papers contained details of financial holdings and offshore investments by 100 multinational companies including Apple, Disney, Facebook, Twitter, McDonald's, Uber, Nike, Allergen, Siemens, Walmart and Allianz, who are allegedly avoided billions of dollars in tax using offshore companies. Apple criticized the reports as inaccurate and misleading, saying that it is the largest taxpayer in the world and that it " pays every dollar it owes in every country around the world ". We certainly have not heard the last on this matter yet. The allegations, if proven right, would have implications with regards to corporate governance and ethics. 2. Mohammad bin Salman Remakes Saudi Arabia Few people outside Saudi Arabia had heard of Prince Mohammed bin Salman before his father became king in 2015. In June 2017, after being elevated to the position of crown prince, he engaged McKinseyâ€™s consultants to help design his â€œVision 2030", the sweeping reform agenda aimed at ushering Saudi Arabia into a more open, post-petroleum future. NBC news reports that â€œthe reforms are aimed at transforming the way the world sees Saudi Arabia, wean it off of oil and remake the hermetic Gulf kingdom into a hub of international business, finance and technologyâ€ . The plan also envisaged changing the education curriculum, increasing women's participation in the workforce, and investing in the entertainment sector to help create jobs for young people. Prince Mohammed was also given much of the credit for King Salman's announcement that a ban on women drivers would end in June 2018, despite opposition from conservatives. These reforms would significantly impact the economy, society and culture of the country and the region, and have rippling effects around the world. Iâ€™ll be watching keenly. 3. Bitcoin price Bitcoin caused a financial frenzy in 2017. Its popularity surged last year as its value continued to rise and the promise of cryptocurrency inspired millions around the world to join the exciting, yet risky venture. At the start of the year, its price was hovering around $1,000. It reached its all-time high of $19,843 per coin, which it hit around December 17, 2017, before a sharp fall in which it briefly dipped below $14,000 by the end of the year. Last year also saw Bitcoin gaining more legitimacy among lawmakers and legacy financial companies. Japan passed a law to accept bitcoin as a legal payment method, and Russia has announced that it will legalize the use of cryptocurrencies. On the legitimacy of cryptocurrency as a medium of exchange, expert opinion continues to be divided along the lines of optimism and skepticism. I have not taken any sides yet â€“ still decoding all the tech jargon. 4. Sexual harassment scandals and the rise of #MeToo In early October, reports in The New York Times and The New Yorker revealed that film mogul Harvey Weinstein allegedly lured women into hotel rooms and bars, and sexually harassed or assaulted them in what some have described as an open secret known for years in Hollywood. Later that month, after a tweet from actor Alyssa Milano, who was one of Weinsteinâ€™s accusers, social media was flooded with personal stories of victims of sexual harassment, all using the hashtag #MeToo. By the end of the year, many men in entertainment, business, politics and the news media were publicly condemned for their alleged sexual misconduct and many have lost their jobs as a result, including Weinstein. Earlier in February 2017, a female engineer who used to work at Uber published a blog post about sexual harassment and gender inequality at the company. That blog, and a few subsequent reports of organizational sexism and gender bias at Uber, forced Travis Kalanick, the founder-CEO, to resign from the firm. The #MeToo movement could transform the workplace for women like no other movements or laws did before. Do share your comments and thoughts.

name: ceposta
headline: MCP servers are cropping up all over the enterprise like weeds in a nice lawn. And just like weeds, this can cause problems.
content: MCP servers are cropping up all over the enterprise like weeds in a nice lawn. And just like weeds, this can cause problems. MCP servers should be secured, but how? The official spec says use OAuth , but that is not appropriate within an enterprise organization. On a recent LinkedIn post I made the point: Any internal enterprise MCP client / AI agent that communicates to an [remote] MCP server should be secured with enterprise SSO. If the agent is acting autonomously, then agent identity should be enforced. But that is for a different post â€¦ (check out my 5 part series on Entra Agent ID). A lot of enterprise organizations use Microsoft Entra ID for their enterprise IdP. In this blog, we take a look at securing ALL MCP access with Entra ID SSO. SSO has been around for a long time, so whatâ€™s the big difference here? They main thing is SSO is usually done in browser based applications. MCP clients are not usually browser applications. For example, VS code, Cursor, Claude, and other AI agents can run on a desktop, mobile, or cloud environment. A browser may be â€œaroundâ€ but they are not always the direct interface. So for us to accomplish SSO from an MCP client to an MCP server, the MCP protocol must support it. OIDC is based on OAuth, and we can perform OIDC logins by leveraging the MCP Authorization spec. And we can do this consistently for all agents/MCP clients regardless of what the backend MCP server is (ie, running within enterprise, hosted by a vendor, SaaS, etc). By tying to enterprise SSO we can apply policy to the MCP usage before it reaches the MCP server. Is this client allowed to access this MCP server? What tools are they allowed to see? Agentgateway is a powerful opensource (Linux Foundation) MCP gateway that implements the MCP Authorization spec. That means we donâ€™t have to try and re-write all MCP servers to use Entra. We can do it automatically from an MCP gateway. Letâ€™s look at an example configuration for Agentgateway: mcpAuthentication: mode: strict issuer: https://sts.windows.net/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/ jwks: url: https://login.microsoftonline.com/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/discovery/v2.0/keys audiences: - api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec resourceMetadata: authorizationServers: - https://login.microsoftonline.com/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/v2.0 resource: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp scopesSupported: - api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access # - openid # - profile bearerMethodsSupported: - header - body - query resourceDocumentation: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/docs resourcePolicyUri: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/policies This piece of YAML is all thatâ€™s needed to implement the MCP Authorization spec to force SSO flows to ANY MCP server hosted on the gateway. The real detail is in how we configure Entra for this. Digging into Entra ID for MCP SSO To use Entra ID for this, we need to set up an Entra App Registration. This will be used to represent our Agentgateway. Can the MCP client access our Agentgateway? We want the Entra ID tokens to be scoped for this. Any other complex authorization policy can be handled with Agentgateway and potentially calling out to a ReBAC engine like OpenFGA . This Entra stuff takes some attention to detail, so letâ€™s follow it step by step setting up an App Registration for Agentgateway. Step 1. Create App Registration Click â€œCreate Applicationâ€ to begin the registration process. We wonâ€™t add any redirect URIs since this app is just used to represent the Agentgateway application, it wonâ€™t be doing any oauth flows itself. The MCP clients do that. Step 2. App Registration Configured Once the application registration is created, you can see things like itâ€™s service principal / client_id (b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec in our case). You donâ€™t need to add any credentials to this app, but we do want to configure scopes that can be requested so that Entra can correctly configure the aud claim in any tokens it issues. Step 3. Add Scopes Click â€œExpose an APIâ€ â€“> â€œAdd a Scopeâ€: Step 4. Configure Scope for Agentgateway access Adding a new scope called mcp_access, leave it as Admin consent and fill in some details that would be displayed on any consent screens. To request the scope, you use the full scope name: api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access Step 5. (Optional - Recommended) add pre-consented Clients Lastly, we can configure which clients are allowed to request these scopes. For example, we can add the public VS Code client (ie, itâ€™s baked into VS code): aebc6443-996d-45c2-90f0-388ff96faa56. Testing MCP SSO + Entra We can run our agentgateway (see source code ): agentgateway -f ./config/agentgateway.yaml And if we go to VS Code, we can add our new server: Step 1. Add MCP Server Step 2. Configure Streamable HTTP MCP Server Step 3. Configure MCP URL Step 4. Agree to Peform SSO Login Step 5. Review MCP Config in mcp.json Using your own MCP Clients In VS Code (and Cursor, Claude, etc) the MCP client ID is baked in. But if you have your own MCP clients, or AI agents, or just want to configure your own OAuth clients for MCP access, you can do that in the Entra dashboard. Step 1. Create a new App Registration (Public client is fine) Step 2. Configure correct Redirect URIs At this point you can use your own OAuth client_ids. Caveat for MCP Inspector MCP Inspector very closely follows the MCP Authorization spec, and unforunately for Entra ID this casues some issues. For example, if we take a look at our OAuth Protected Resource Metadata (PRM): { "resource": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp", "authorization_servers": [ "https://login.microsoftonline.com/5e7d8166-7876-4755-a1a4-b476d4a344f6/v2.0" ], "scopes_supported": [ "api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access" ], "bearer_methods_supported": [ "header", "body", "query" ], "resource_documentation": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/docs", "resource_policy_uri": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/policies", "mcp_protocol_version": "2025-06-18", "resource_type": "mcp-server" } You can see our Agentgateway correctly returns the PRM. A client should be able to automatically continue the OAuth/OIDC flow from this. HOWEVER. You can see the resource field gets set to "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp", This causes an issue in MCP inspector (not VS Code or other clients) because MCP inspector uses this field in the Authorization request. It sets the resource parameter based on this value (according to spec): resource=https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp scope=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec%2Fmcp_access The problem is, this is not the correct resource in Entra. The correct resouce in entra is our api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec client_id. If we configure the Agentgateway to return this in our PRM, then that breaks the rest of the OAuth flow, since thatâ€™s not the real URL for our MCP resource. The fix here is to: Make MCP Inspector more flexible to override the resource sent in the auth flows Use a verified custom domain the app registration resource URI. If you are doing this in production, youâ€™d want to user a verified custom domain. Alternatively, in your custom MCP clients, make a way to override the resource parameter when calling tha authorize endpoint and use the real client_id like this example: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<TENANT_ID>/oauth2/v2.0/authorize? response_type=code& client_id=9beda151-9370-42f2-a2f7-17933c5c5a7c& code_challenge=BPfzTvHnOhmbZyB8aIW3sCG69vLmF_hG3aQRvl5C31s& code_challenge_method=S256& redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A6274%2Foauth%2Fcallback%2Fdebug& state=38158e70909ff3264e129b13b3927b34dc299a7d2dea3b9ee62ca0f181e83db5& scope=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec%2Fmcp_access& resource=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec Wrapping Up The right pattern for enterprise MCP usage is to tie access to the internal IdP and SSO. All policy should be written against these user IDs (and groups, claims, etc). For more complex auth flows that require cross-identity OAuth ie, like if you need to call GitHub MCP servers, or Databricks, etc each which have their own IdP separate from enterprise IdP, then you can do that also with Agentgateway Enterprise:

name: stockearth
headline: The announcement on February 6, 2026, marks the completion of a major structural shift for BlackRock: the full "bridge" between public and private market data.
content: The announcement on February 6, 2026, marks the completion of a major structural shift for BlackRock : the full "bridge" between public and private market data. By integrating Preqin (which BlackRock acquired for $3.2 billion in 2025) directly into eFront and Aladdin , they have essentially built a " Bloomberg Terminal for private assets." Until now, institutional investors had to toggle between different systems: one for their stocks and bonds ( Aladdin ), one for their internal private equity data ( eFront ), and a third for market research and benchmarking ( Preqin ). This isn't just for big banks. BlackRock â€™s goal is to bring Private Equity to the masses. By making private assets as easy to track and trade as public stocks, BlackRock is preparing for a world where your 401(k) or personal brokerage account includes small "tokens" of private infrastructure or private debt. Sloane Collins , BlackRock â€™s Head of Product for Aladdin Private Markets, stated that this integration "narrows the gap" between how the world treats public and private assets. It effectively ends the era where private equity was a "black box."

name: amiya
headline: That claude skill you installed via npm is actually a loaded gun pointing at your database.
content: That claude skill you installed via npm is actually a loaded gun pointing at your database. Hereâ€™s how a simple text file is nuking production systems (and why you clicked install). We are officially automating our own breaches and calling it "efficiency" ğŸ’€. Installing AI "skills" via npm right now is like signing a marriage license where your partner wrote "I get the house, the dog, and your kidneys" in white text on white paper. The Human View: You see a harmless, standard markdown file. The AI View: It reads the invisible HTML tags (which your viewer doesn't render) and obediently executes the malicious prompts buried inside. It gets worse. AI agents are now "hallucinating" npm packages that donâ€™t exist. Attackers spot these requests in public logs, create a malicious package with that *exact* name, and wait for your agent to find it and auto-install it. You aren't just downloading a library. You are handing over your API keys to a bot that thinks it's helping ğŸ“¦. If you think `npm install` is safe for autonomous agents, you are the vulnerability. We are building systems that don't just have security holesâ€”they actively go out and fetch them. Be honest: When was the last time you actually read the code inside your node_modules folder? How do you handle the volume? ğŸ‘‡ #GenAI #CyberSecurity #DevOps #PromptInjection #npm

name: gplhegde
headline: In the AI era, productivity comes down to two skills:
content: In the AI era, productivity comes down to two skills: The ability to ignore the noise long enough to build something useful. The ability to create noise once you have. Most people are stuck doing one without the other. The builders stay invisible. The loud ones ship nothing. The ones who win? They do both â€” in that order.

name: abidalee
headline: Everyone is different and has different talents and gifts. Teachers, parents, friends, family, colleagues, managers and leaders should identify the strengths, their likes, their interests, and then guide them in the right direction to avoid frustration in the long run Otherwise people will struggle
content: Everyone is different and has different talents and gifts. Teachers, parents, friends, family, colleagues, managers and leaders should identify the strengths, their likes, their interests, and then guide them in the right direction to avoid frustration in the long run Otherwise people will struggle a lot at school, then at job to perform any given task and would think that they are incompetent and incapable of doing anything. They will be frustrated and demotivated all the time and it will result in low self-esteem. It is, therefore, our duty to help everyone identify their true potential and ensure they are given appropriate direction, support, and encouragement to pursue what they love and believe in.

name: vinay-karumuri-19047568
headline: Struggling to scale your Playwright tests in Kubernetes?
content: Struggling to scale your Playwright tests in Kubernetes? You're not alone. Playwright is fast, but it lacks a native Selenium Grid-like Hub for distributed execution. We faced this head-on and decided to build the solution ourselves: a custom, lightweight Playwright Hub designed for Kubernetes. In my latest article, I break down how we built a custom Playwright Hub that gives you: âœ… Proactive, queue-based autoscaling with KEDA (not reactive CPU scaling!) âœ… Intelligent session routing and request queuing âœ… Full observability with Prometheus metrics It's the Selenium Grid-like power you've been wanting for your Playwright tests. Learn more about this in this article. Stop test timeouts and start scaling smartly. Read my article: https://lnkd.in/gXR8dheb #Playwright #Selenium #DevOps #Kubernetes #KEDA #Automation #SoftwareEngineering

name: pranay-mathur-b85020139
headline: Most GenAI systems focus on prompts.
content: Most GenAI systems focus on prompts. I focused on something else: How do you govern LLMs in production? I built a 3-tier LLM Observability & Control Plane designed for reliability, cost control, and safe failure. Architecture: â€¢ Tier 1 â€” Deterministic regex guardrails (~1ms) â€¢ Tier 2 â€” Embedding-based semantic detection (~250ms) â€¢ Tier 3 â€” LangGraph agent escalation (~3s) System capabilities: â€¢ 95/4/1 cost-aware routing â€¢ Deterministic block / fallback enforcement â€¢ Multi-provider support (Groq + Ollama) â€¢ Prompt injection & hallucination detection â€¢ Prometheus metrics & health monitoring â€¢ Persistent audit logging â€¢ 72 automated tests (98.6% pass rate) The core philosophy is simple: LLMs should be treated as unreliable dependencies. Production systems must enforce control, not trust. This is governance-first AI infrastructure. #LLMOps #AIInfrastructure #GenAI #AIEngineering #MLOps

name: ternpohlim
headline: Returning to Singapore Management University always feels like coming home.
content: Returning to Singapore Management University always feels like coming home. I graduated in 2014 with a Finance degree, but I returned this week to speak about a completely different world: Artificial Intelligence. During the panel with SMU Business Intelligence and Analytics , the students asked the hard question: â€œHow do we find jobs in this current climate?â€ My answer: Donâ€™t let your degree define your career. I pivoted from Finance to AI because I looked at what was on the horizon. The specific subject you study matters less than our judgment. We must spot the trends, build the expertise early, and be ready when the role appears. It was great to share the stage with my batchmate Adrian Lee to share our experiences and discuss internship opportunities. Thanks Singapore Management University for the platform, and to my Deloitte colleagues Meng Jie Tan and Min Jia Chan for the invitation. It is always a joy to give back to the community that gave me my start. #SMU #Deloitte #AI #CareerAdvice #Alumni

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Who is a man, and Who is a Woman? Are we not one? Yes, indeed. Gender equality is no longer a myth, rather, it's high time that we all see gender as a spectrum instead of two sets of opposing ideals.
content: Who is a man, and Who is a Woman? Are we not one? Yes, indeed. Gender equality is no longer a myth, rather, it's high time that we all see gender as a spectrum instead of two sets of opposing ideals. The soul has no gender, and so do I, rather, we all. A sustainable and successful work environment demands a plethora of skills and competencies, and certainly that's not achievable from any one group of people having a particular arrangement of chromosomes. Men tend to be decisive, confident and bold while taking risks, whereas, women tend to be protective, inclusive, detail-oriented and aware. Henceforth, for a better tomorrow, what is really needed is to provide the full array of expertise to all people, and not just some. We all believe that teamwork is the heart of great achievement. True teamwork means the team members are open to share ideas, help one another, complement each other and be receptive to feedback. If that is so, then diverse teams significantly contribute more towards productivity. To achieve such a harmonious experience, all that we need is to have a general awareness on gender intelligence. To put it simple, we need to appreciate our differences and look forward towards ways of complementing them while being careful to our own individuality; because one can only make a difference, but together we can rock the world. The biggest example for this is my company, SAP Labs India. SAP Labs India is a hotspot of diversity and inclusiveness. The company values men and women in equality endowed with the same dignity. There are equal opportunities, appreciation and celebration for both the sex, because what matters here is the talent, the abilities, the versatility and the prowess.We have a lot of work to do and we get there by working together as our strength lies in the differences and not in the sameness. We make gender equality a lived reality, a cherished virtue and a promising opportunity for one and all. On the advent of International Men's Day 2017, I look forward to resolve the problem with gender that prescribes how we should be, rather than recognizing how we are. #diversity #diversityandinclusion #genderdiversity #genderequity #genderintelligenc e

name: saurav-pattnaik-1b73b1151
headline: Thereâ€™s just too much to read.
content: Thereâ€™s just too much to read. Every week there are new research papers, blogs, and articles, and I kept feeling stuck at the same point: where do I even start? So I built two small side projects for myself: a weekly research paper tracker a weekly articles digest across AI, Python, Data Science, and Math The goal was simple: reduce the noise and make it easier to stay consistent. Instead of searching endlessly, I just open it, pick something, and read. Itâ€™s been a small but meaningful improvement to how I keep myself up to date. If information overload sounds familiar, youâ€™re not alone. Weekly Articles - https://lnkd.in/gVEtmdfE Weekly Research Paper - https://lnkd.in/gfdK2ThX Both projects are easily configurable, refresh automatically every week with new recommendations and anyone can tweak them to their interests and deploy their own version using GitHub Pages and GitHub Actions. Thanks!

name: ria-rustagi
headline: This 60-year-old company solved my problem with a single 10-second video and replaced my hardware in under 48 hours.
content: This 60-year-old company solved my problem with a single 10-second video and replaced my hardware in under 48 hours. Every hardware startup needs to hear this story. I found the gold standard for hardware startups, And it isnâ€™t in Silicon Valley. Itâ€™s in Alleppey, Kerala. When I was pregnant, I bought a recliner from them. I needed it for my back while working. I knew Iâ€™d need it even more once the baby arrived. Those long, sleepless nights, Rocking her to sleep, Taking care of my posture. It has been a total savior. If anyone asks me for the #1 "must-have" for expecting parents? It is this recliner. But the product isnâ€™t even the best part. The service is seamless. In my experience, itâ€™s better than Apple. Twice, I had an issue. All they asked for was a quick video. Within 48 hours, a new one was shipped or a technician was at my door. The company is Duroflex . As a hardware startup founder, Iâ€™m in awe. Hardware is hard. It fails. You canâ€™t predict every glitch or break. But when it happens, the only thing that matters is how you handle the upset customer. Duroflex has been doing this since 1963. Their founder, P.C. Mathew, started in the backwaters of Kerala. Today, they are a 1,000-crore legacy brand. But they still act with the speed of a D2C startup. The lesson for us founders? The customer might not always be right. But giving them the faith that you are always there? That makes them a customer for life. It turns them into an influencer at no cost. And it gets you a testimonial like this for free. Build the hardware. But more importantly, build the faith. Yasir Umar Arpita Yadav Mukul Bansal

name: petelauop
headline: The energy from our OPPO engineers is truly inspiring these days.
content: The energy from our OPPO engineers is truly inspiring these days. This time of year, I always witness such incredible dedication. It's not about showing off, but about truly making technology bring those better, more delightful, more reassuring moments into our everyday. This year, we've given our Gold Award for Leading Imaging Technology to our LUMO algorithm team. Congratulations to them! To be honest, we haven't given this award out for five whole years. We always hold to the belief: "Better empty than compromised." LUMO is built on real, self-developed hard-core tech. It means you can take natural, great-looking portraits effortlessly. It handles challenging situations like backlight, low light, and even those quick shots of kids running, with ease. And with our Danxia True-Color lens, difficult lighting won't stop you from taking amazing portraits. That's why I'm so confident in saying we are the best choice for portraits. Because behind every great shot, there are dedicated engineers who truly care about getting it right for you.

name: khoslaj
headline: Was thinking about a feature we are building in hostbento and ended up with some conflicting thoughts.
content: Was thinking about a feature we are building in hostbento and ended up with some conflicting thoughts. It started with a train ride. Phone away. Felt long. Same train back, scrolling. Felt like half the time. That got me thinking: We spend billions making transportation faster â€” bullet trains, supersonic jets, hyperloops.But what if the real innovation isn't faster travel... it's making slow travel feel fast? A wealthy person takes a 1-hour flight. A less wealthy person takes a 6-hour bus. But if that bus rider is absorbed in TikTok or Instagram â€” have we narrowed the experiential gap? In medicine, we treat symptoms all the time. Should building software be any different?If the goal is maximum impact â€” is building painkillers more important than cures? Should software that makes you lose the sense of time be so frowned upon? I don't have the answer. Do you?

name: debashishghosh1
headline: The Outward Mindset: Seeing Beyond Ourselves by The Arbinger Institute If you are looking the authorâ€™s name, you are not getting one! This book builds on Arbinger Instituteâ€™s 35 years of work helping individuals and organizations to be more effective, innovative and collaborative. It essentially tal
content: The Outward Mindset: Seeing Beyond Ourselves by The Arbinger Institute If you are looking the authorâ€™s name, you are not getting one! This book builds on Arbinger Instituteâ€™s 35 years of work helping individuals and organizations to be more effective, innovative and collaborative. It essentially talks about how having the right mindset is the key to success and growth of any organization â€“ as mindsets drive behaviors and behaviors drive results. There are two mindsets â€“ Outward and Inward. With an outward mindset, we see others as people like ourselves, whose needs, objectives and challenges matter to us. An inward mindset, on the other hand, is very self-focused, where we see others as objects and consider only those options that would advance and protect our own agendas. By sharing true and compelling stories of individual leaders and client organizations, Arbinger leads us to the journey of achieving outward mindset. If you are looking for a â€œhow toâ€ guide to drive organizational culture and change in your organization, this is the book to read. I know it because my own organization has greatly benefitted by implementing the profound guidance and tools from this book and from another Arbinger masterpiece â€œLeadership and Self-deceptionâ€. Thinking Fast and Slow: Daniel Kahneman I saw this book featuring in every â€œBest-Business-Books-Of-All-Timeâ€ List. I had to read it! I did, and it is indeed one of the greatest books of all time! This book summarizes Nobel-laureate Daniel Kahnemanâ€™s research of over three decades. The central theme of this is about how human beings use two different â€œsystemsâ€ for making decisions and judgments. System 1 is fast, intuitive, unconscious and emotional. System 2 is slow, logical, effortful and calculating. Kahneman covers a lifetime of experiments in order to highlight the differences between these two systems and how they arrive at different results even given the same inputs. Each chapter in the book is a gem, covering various facets of decision-making backed by empirical research. I favorite in the one where he takes on Jim Collins and his best-selling book â€œGood To Greatâ€. Unlike Collinsâ€™ claim that inspirational leadership and culture are the drivers behind successful organizations, Kahneman (statistically) argues that luck and a regression to the mean are more impactful than Collins credits. An interesting diversity of thoughts of two great thinkers! This is not a book for those who have a-book-every-week goals. This is a slow read. You will need to use your System 2. Moonwalking with Einstein: Joshua Foer Joshua Foer was a young journalist when he went to cover the United States Memory Championship. He was so fascinated by the idea of memory improvement and with the â€œmemory athletesâ€ that he actually went on to participate in the Championship the following year. And won it! I read about this incredible story in another article and I was hooked immediately. I started reading the book expecting to read about his incredible and personal journey from being a reporter to a memory champion within a year. But the book offers much more. Besides being a personal account, the book chronicles the history and transformation of human memory by drawing on cutting-edge research. It also shares the techniques that humankind has used to improve memory. Personally, I have always struggled with my memory. I have an amazing (dis)ability to forget names, articles, places etc. within a very short time. If you are someone like me and want to improve your memory, read this book. Winning on HR Analytics: Soundararajan and Singh I have been reading up a lot on HR Analytics off late. This book was the first one I picked on this subject. I like it when business books are written by successful business professionals. Both Soundararajan and Singh have had hugely successful careers on their own. Their experience shows in their writing. The book does not try to impress you by being esoteric and intellectualistic. What you get here are some practical, insightful case studies written with a focus on implementation. A word of caution though. This is not a book for senior HR professionals with a deep exposure to analytics. If you are looking to learn advanced statistical tools like regression, variance, decision tree etc., this one is not for you (for that, I recommend â€“ â€œBusiness Analytics: The Science of Data - Driven Decision Makingâ€ by U Dinesh Kumar). This one for HR professionals, young or otherwise, who are interested in fundamentals. This is the first book on HR Analytics they should read. Tuesdays with Morrie: Mitch Albom A true, poignant account of the author (Mitch Albom is a journalist and best-selling author) and Morrie Schwartz, the college professor who had taught him nearly 20 years before. While Albom was working a sports columnist for the Detroit Free Press , he saw his professor Morrie Schwartz appear on television recounting his experience of dealing with ALS (ALS is a non-curable disease that causes the death of neurons controlling the voluntary muscles, resulting in a slow and painful death of the afflicted) . An ensuing newspaper strike allows Albom to visit Schwartz every week, on Tuesdays. The book recounts each of the fourteen visits Albom made to Schwartz, before his eventual death. In each of these 14 visits (chapters in the book), Schwartz shares his experiences and his own interpretations of lifeâ€™s events, with generous dollops of positivity and sense of humor. I loved all the Tuesdays. But if you are in the bookstore, pick it up and read the fifth Tuesday where Schwartz talk about his views on family. Soul-stirring. Catalyst: Chandramouli Venkatesan This is a book on career management written by someone who had a hugely successful corporate career. Mouli, as he is commonly called, has served in senior capacities, including as CEO and MD, in major organizations such as Asian Paints, Cadbury and Pidilite. In this book, Mouli captured real insights from everyday events and offers practical advice on career. I loved his take on some of the most discussed career-related topics, such as long stints in a company and impact of boss in oneâ€™s career. There is no dearth of books on career growth and professional success. This one is different because it draws from Mouliâ€™s personal experience and insights. I highly recommend it for young professionals launching their careers. For experienced professionals, I can assure you some â€œahaâ€ moments. Which are the books you read recently and really liked? Would love to know about those. Happy reading!

name: ankitnayaketh
headline: EpsteinFiles-RAG: Building a RAG Pipeline on 2M+ Pages
content: EpsteinFiles-RAG: Building a RAG Pipeline on 2M+ Pages I love playing around with RAG and AI, optimizing every layer to squeeze out better performance. Last night I thought: why not tackle something massive? Took the Epstein Files dataset from Hugging Face (teyler/epstein-files-20k) â€“ 2 million+ pages of trending news and documents. The cleaning, chunking, and optimization challenges are exactly what excites me. What I built: - Full RAG pipeline with optimized data processing - Processed 2M+ pages (cleaning, chunking, vectorization) - Semantic search & Q&A over massive dataset - Constantly tweaking for better retrieval & performance - Python, MIT Licensed, open source Why I built this: Itâ€™s trending, real-world data at scale, the perfect playground. When you operate at scale, every optimization matters. This project lets me experiment with RAG architectures, data pipelines, and AI performance tuning on real-world workloads. Repo: https://lnkd.in/gkw_p-Ti Open to ideas, optimizations, and technical discussions!

name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
headline: ğŸš€ Just experimented something I'm really excited about â€” a fully autonomous content pipeline that takes a single topic and generates a blog post, infographic, and slide deck without any human intervention.
content: ğŸš€ Just experimented something I'm really excited about â€” a fully autonomous content pipeline that takes a single topic and generates a blog post, infographic, and slide deck without any human intervention. The secret? Combining three powerful technologies: ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜„ğ—”ğ—œ â€” 5 specialized AI agents working as a team (research librarian, QA gate checker, blog writer, infographic designer, slide producer) ğ— ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜…ğ˜ ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—¹ (ğ— ğ—–ğ—£) â€” standardized tool access with permission isolation so each agent only touches what it should ğ—šğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¡ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¸ğ—Ÿğ—  â€” deep web research + source-grounded content generation One design choice I'm most proud of: a hybrid architecture where LLM agents handle the reasoning, but a plain Python polling gate handles the waiting. No burning tokens on 10 minutes of "are we there yet?" calls â€” just a simple while loop with subprocess calls. Zero cost, zero hallucination risk. The result? â†’ Researches the topic across the web â†’ Ingests sources into NotebookLM â†’ Waits patiently until ready (deterministic gate) â†’ Generates 3 artifacts: blog, infographic, slides â†’ Downloads everything to organized output folders Key lessons from building this: âœ… Separate concerns into phases â€” don't let one mega-agent do everything âœ… Use deterministic gates between async operations â€” LLMs are terrible pollers âœ… Isolate tool permissions per agent â€” principle of least privilege via MCP filters âœ… Always verify â€” add Python-level checks after every agent step The future of AI isn't one model doing everything. It's teams of specialized agents with clear roles, working through well-defined interfaces. Wrote a detailed Medium post breaking down the full architecture, tech stack, and CrewAI + MCP implementation #AI #CrewAI #MCP #AgenticAI #NotebookLM #Automation #GenerativeAI #LLM #MultiAgentSystems #BuildInPublic

name: gplhegde
headline: We just redefined website templates for the AI era.
content: We just redefined website templates for the AI era. When we launched hostbento , we assumed people would chat with AI to build hyper-personalized websites. We were wrong. Turns out, people still end up with generic sites that don't reflect their actual business. "Hey ChatGPT, build me a real estate website" â†’ generic template that could be for anyone. The real problem isn't how to build. It's what to build. After talking to marketers and agencies, we learned they get stuck on: - What pages do I actually need? - How should this look for my industry? - What content goes where? So we built templates. But not traditional ones. Hostbento templates define your entire design system, not just a page. Pick a template â†’ AI adapts the design to your business and content. The template is a reference. AI does the customization. That's what templates should be in the AI era. Got website ideas? We got design system defined for you. Check them out in the comment. #WebsiteTemplate #WebDesign #AIWebsite

name: testerops
headline: Found this interesting post on Quora, which was also published in Forbes. This answer by Nachiket Naik is brilliant round -up of many of the programmers out there- even in MNC's.
content: Found this interesting post on Quora, which was also published in Forbes. This answer by Nachiket Naik is brilliant round -up of many of the programmers out there- even in MNC's. 1) The StackOverflow bot: This person ran into an error, did a quick Google search and applied the first solution they found. The problem here is not that of copying from Stackoverflow. I think there are more solutions on Stackoverflow than any reference guide or manual. Don't get me wrong, it's a wonderful resource, if not the best. The problem is the robotic application of it without understanding the consequences. The problem is the application of it without fully understanding the context of it and whether it really applies to the current problem at hand. More often than not, I have seen people believe more of what they see on online forums than the code/system in front of them. 2) The I-am-not-a-tester: I don't need to test the code, that is the job of the testers. I don't think that even in this age of mature Agile methodologies, this attitude has waned. There is still an inertia against testing their code. Part of it comes from lacking the interest to set up a testing environment and partly from lack of coherent knowledge of testing. (Is it also partly due to an unspoken stigma against testers in the developer community.) 3) The I-hate-documentation: Some people believe that code documentation must be poetic and hence they lack the skill to do it, ergo not their job. In my opinion, these are the #1 foes of sustainable software. Good software is not software that provides a million cool features. Good software is one that has a few good features that are used consistently by many people and read/updated/modified by a thousand . This brand of developers who believes less in technical communication and precise and detailed documentation is the greatest weed to a company's success. 4) The ugly: My code works, but: I have variables named x, flag, str, arr, etc. Most of what I write is in one giant method. There is no indentation. No consistent coding convention or style. Global variables spewed all over the place, etc. This is the most annoying thing for me personally. It's not the issue that the code is bad. It could potentially be the greatest piece of code written. But if a diamond necklace is buried in the debris of the Titanic, nobody will find it, and nobody will want to clean it, wear it, use it. 5) The short-term investor: He codes. He deploys. He moves on. No attempt to learn the problem. No interest in the domain. Just give this guy a piece of code, he will slog on it overnight and hand it over. You got a fix/working software. Nothing more achieved from it. Sometimes, it's important that you have certain selfishness in the developer, one who not only cares about the deadline, but also cares about what he/she got to learn from it. 6) The protester: "I didn't do this". "This looks bad". "Not my problem". "This isn't related really to my fix, but someone way over there made a mistake". "I hate this (loop this sentence 10 times a day)", "I can't fix this, get the person who made this code to fix it". The person who coded that mistake has moved on, when will you? 7) The dictator: My way or the highway is their motto. It's their "ideas" vs "your ideas", not "project ideas". It's their solution vs your solution. I bet there will be an argument for sure. Somehow they will keep coming back to a part of code that you implemented. It somehow discomforts them even if it works, tests, and looks perfectly fine. This person is a big bottleneck to productivity and will be the first person to crumble under pressure and start pointing fingers. This person is not good for the team, however experienced/good a developer he may be. 8) The overcautious: The Java developer who just froze when he learned that he would have to write a Python script. The developer who panicked on learning that something in the registry needs changing. The developer who cringes at having to input things in the database. These people will do anything to avoid getting out of their comfort zone. They have weird superstitions related to having to touch certain parts of the system. I have learned, from personal experience, that this phenomenon is common with new developers. Good developers show a tendency to slowly/swiftly move out of their comfort zone in exploration. 9) The careless: Forgets to take a backup, snapshots, has multiple working directories of code, leaves system out, prints in production code, etc. Again, this is a newbie tendency and gets better with more professional exposure. 10) The lazy pseudo-hacker: They pride themselves at being able to trick the system into working. They find magical solutions to seemingly complex problems. My experience says that 9 out of 10 times, it's just a facade. The hack is bad and will crash sooner or later and will cost much more than having to deal with it, with extra time right now.

name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
headline: Built a NotebookLM-style assistant that grounds answers in your own sources with citations, memory, and optional podcast output.
content: Built a NotebookLM-style assistant that grounds answers in your own sources with citations, memory, and optional podcast output. The system ingests PDFs, text, web pages, YouTube, and audio, chunks and embeds them, stores vectors in ChromaDB, retrieves relevant context, and generates cited responses via OpenAI or Anthropic. Zep adds conversation continuity, while AssemblyAI and ElevenLabs power transcription and podcast audio. Tech stack: Streamlit, PyMuPDF, FastEmbed, ChromaDB, CrewAI, AssemblyAI, Firecrawl, Zep, ElevenLabs. Key takeaways: - Modular RAG pipeline with clean separation of ingestion, retrieval, generation, and memory. - Strong UX focus with citation tooltips and studio-style audio outputs. - Provider-agnostic LLM layer with task-based model selection. #RAG , #LLM , #Streamlit , #ChromaDB , #AssemblyAI , #ElevenLabs , #Zep

name: oliver-reeves
headline: After a year and a half of devastation on the global market things are finally starting to look up. As I am sure many developers and hiring managers in the tech industry are noticing, the job market is getting more competitive by the day and it isnâ€™t country-specific.
content: After a year and a half of devastation on the global market things are finally starting to look up. As I am sure many developers and hiring managers in the tech industry are noticing, the job market is getting more competitive by the day and it isnâ€™t country-specific. Things are beginning to pick up and get competitive, I can foresee it getting more difficult to hire and to also retain developer talent across all countriesâ€™ markets. This is good news for developers, as it raises the standards in working environments and company culture. In my opinion, it is as important for companies to start reconsidering what they are doing to keep the developers that work for them happy, healthy and mentally stimulated. Work benefits can come in many forms. From flexible work arrangements to various opportunities for developers to up-skill themselves, the methods are endless. So, are you listening to your developer team? Are their opinions valued? Do you actually care about their wellbeing? Whatever is going on with your dev team, maybe it is time to reassess what you can do to improve your teamâ€™s day to day life. Not only does it help employees feel appreciated and looked after, it benefits you as a business owner too. As companies are aware, there are many options out there for developers to choose from. In order to attract the best talent, are you doing anything to set yourself up differently compared to other companies? Yes your product might be good and it might be the next best thing, and developers â€œshould feel lucky to be part of the missionâ€, but that really is not enough. I can assure you that every founder of a business out there will say that their product will be the next big thing and that developers will be lucky to be part of the mission, but in this market having this approach could make hiring and retaining talent a big issue.

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: What differentiates SAP Labs from its competitors is the care it takes of its employees. The very existence of Diversity & Inclusion Team is a testament to SAPâ€™s commitment in creating and maintaining a great place to work! Keeping the ethos of SAP in mind, the Diversity & Inclusion arm of SAP Labs
content: What differentiates SAP Labs from its competitors is the care it takes of its employees. The very existence of Diversity & Inclusion Team is a testament to SAPâ€™s commitment in creating and maintaining a great place to work! Keeping the ethos of SAP in mind, the Diversity & Inclusion arm of SAP Labs India (D&I, India) designed and executed the Cross Generational Mentorship Program , which presented the T1 community across all entities (Labs, Ariba, SDC, Concur, Success factors, Fieldglass) and locations (Bangalore, Gurgaon, Pune, Mumbai) with an opportunity to reverse mentor senior colleagues and get mentored by them. The intent was to bridge the gap between the senior and junior colleagues so that both equally benefit from insightful conversations across various domains. Indeed, it was all about breaking biases and fostering, and deepening the learning curve and productivity that leads to success. It is often said that learning something new from a person from a completely different background does much more than developing skills. It makes us lower our prejudices, release preconceived biases, invoke our will, and work on personal network building. And thatâ€™s what happened in Cross Generational Mentorship, where the young talents had to reverse mentor senior colleagues and at the same time get mentored by them. The young talents and senior colleagues had different topics of interest, different perspectives, different mindsets, and more. Yet they were united by the third friend called Cross Generational Mentorship. The concept of Cross Generational Mentorship appeared exceptionally disruptive to both my mentor Ujjwal Nath, Development Manager - Globalization Services and me. Having a T1 reverse mentor for someone who is an accomplished force in the industry confounded me. In an industry where every second day is path-breaking, keeping up with the pace is imperative. It is programs like these that allow people like me to stay on top of an ever-changing ecosystem. While the program expands the horizon for senior members, it opens doors for junior colleagues as well. Truth is, if anyone has been in the industry for at least 6 months, she/he must have heard that networking is key. However, one wonders, how can a junior colleague network? Well, ETs do join in a group and form strong bonds with their peers, but a network is far more valuable when it is diverse. Therefore, Cross Generational Mentorship is the perfect springboard for a junior colleague to diversify her/his network. Besides the networking aspect, a T1 gets to pick on the best brains and learns to imbibe attributes that have made seasoned individuals successful. The current program was kickstarted by D&I Team through setting up the context for the program; they did so through an orientation program in which they invited both the T1s and the senior officials. The program had a special Breaking Gen Myth workshop along with roll out of topics and the new gamification approach, that makes it even more competitive this time, to all the participants. While the ETs chose topics that they would like to mentor on, senior officials chose topics, from the same pool, that they wished to be mentored on. Based on the topics selected, all the participants were paired into sub-groups, which mostly consisted of one senior official and one/two T1s. I was mapped with Ujjwal and successfully completed 7 sessions (both theoretical and hands-on) on multiple topics like Mobile & Social Media, The Generation Game, Career Aspiration Management, How to Climb Up the Ladder, Crowdsourcing Applications, Conversational AI, Cyber Security & Cyber Privacy and Data Boom. From different perspectives we talked, we discussed, we chatted, we debated, and yes, we learned. Ujjwal's coaching sessions paved a path for me on how to reach my short term and long-term goals and make it a reality, whereas my mentoring sessions inspired him to be an active contributor to D&I and had nominated this program to all other senior leaders. In short, it was a platform where lots of questions were asked and answered, lots of discussions happened, and finally resulted in great bonding. Overall, Cross Generational Mentorship not only made our branches reach for the skies but also made our roots go deep. Coming to the close of this blog, I am elated to be a part of something so refreshing. The more I invested in the program, the more I gained from it. Therefore, I urge each T1 or senior colleague reading to give the program a chance. I also would like to laud every participant who took time out to participate in the program, enabling each other to unlock undiscovered areas.
