name: amrit-pattnaik-2410ab8
headline: ğŸš€ Why did Kimi K2.5 & Arcee Trinity Large ditch AdamW for Muon?
content: ğŸš€ Why did Kimi K2.5 & Arcee Trinity Large ditch AdamW for Muon? The release of Kimi K2.5 and Arceeâ€™s Trinity Large introduced clever architectural ideas â€” from Agent Swarm Orchestration to Fine-grained MoEs. But one detail flew under the radar: Both models ditched the industry-standard AdamW optimizer for Muon. While almost all Production Grade LLMs have so far used Adam or AdamW as the optimizer, Kimi has been a pioneer in leveraging this gem in its earlier models (Kimi K2 and Kimi K2 Thinking) and now Arcee has followed suit. I ran a benchmark experiment to find out what makes Muon Optimizer stand out ğŸ§ª Experiment 1 â€” Small Model Setup Hidden Dim: 512 Model Depth: 1 Batch Size: 256 Training Steps: 300 Learning Rate: 1e-2 Total Params: ~ 262K ğŸ“Š Plots 1â€“3 show: ğŸ”» ~50% lower memory usage (Muon vs AdamW) âš¡ Faster convergence ğŸ“‰ Much smoother & more stable training curves ğŸ§ª Experiment 2 â€” Scaled Model Setup Hidden Dim: 1024 Model Depth: 8 Batch Size: 256 Training Steps: 300 Learning Rate: 1e-2 Total Params: ~8.39M ğŸ“Š Plots 4â€“6 confirm: Memory savings persist as depth increases Convergence remains faster and steadier Compute efficiency scales with model size ğŸ”‘ Key Takeaways âœ… ~50% lower memory usage âš¡ ~30â€“50% lower compute (FLOPs) ğŸ¯ More robust to learning-rate changes â†’ less hyperparameter tuning ğŸ§  Amplifies rare gradient directions â†’ better learning of subtle patterns ğŸ“ Normalized update directions â†’ controlled geometric training regime ğŸ’¡ Bottom line: As LLMs grow deeper and wider, Muon scales better than AdamW, making it a compelling optimizer for next-gen open-source and production LLMs. Would be interesting to see if Muon is adopted more broadly in large-scale training pipelines going forward ğŸ‘€ #LLMs #Optimizers #DeepLearning #OpenSourceAI #Muon #AdamW #Kimi K2.5 #ArceeTrinity #GeometryOptimizers

name: sanchit-goyal14
headline: What is ONDC? It is an open protocol network to enable local commerce across segments by engaging with any network-enabled application. In simple words, suppose you want to order milk from the local Kirana shop which accepts Paytm.
content: What is ONDC? It is an open protocol network to enable local commerce across segments by engaging with any network-enabled application. In simple words, suppose you want to order milk from the local Kirana shop which accepts Paytm. Now, you can go to the ONDC platform and directly order from this Kirana shop network. Dunzo might deliver your order and you can pay through Paytm. Different platforms like Paytm, Dunzo, Sellerapp, Gofrugal, etc. need to integrate their application with ONDC. There are many other important players with whom talks are going on, like Google Pay, Phone Pe, Microsoft, Zoho, BHIM, etc. Data Points 4000 + small and big e-commerce companies 500 + logistics companies 20,000 + providing services through e-commerce platforms $200 billion estimated market size of e-commerce by 2026 TAM - 624 million Internet users in India SAM - 478 million ( 76.7% e-commerce penetration) SOM - 100 million ( 80-100 million current e-commerce users who have made at least one purchase and assuming 10% increase due to ONDC) Average Order value for grocery - $21 in 2017 AOV for physical goods - Rs 3600 ($48) in 2016 Market Potential - $2.1 billion for grocery alone and $4.8 billion for physical goods However, if we consider the increment of e-commerce users by 20% due to ONDC push then SOM will be 120 million and market potential for physical goods would reach $5.7 billion. Considering 7% of inflation too for AOV, this number would be easily $8 billion in 2022. I have only considered the B2C physical goods market to reach $8 billion. There is a huge B2B market too and then many other categories in B2C too. Features of ONDC Merchants will be able to reach more consumers Both offline traders and online platforms will come at the same level in terms of digital exposure All transactions will happen through an open platform Operations will be standardized and logistics will become more efficient Higher value for consumers as they can order from any merchant The biggest concern about ONDC is confidentiality and privacy of data which needs to be taken care of by the GoI. Pilot Cities The pilot will be launched in five cities in the initial phase. For launching the pilot, metro and Tier 2 cities have been chosen to see how the technology works. Delhi Bengaluru Bhopal Shillong Coimbatore Value Proposition Merchants : No need to worry about logistics and supply chain, just need to make the catalog available digitally to have visibility for everyone connected to the Internet. Consumers : Convenience in ordering from any merchant they want. Applications : More orders for last-mile logistics partners; offline payments shifting to online payments thus benefiting payment partners too. Government of India : Higher employment opportunities; equal digital presence of offline and online traders; all stakeholders on a common platform so easy to monitor; opportunity for village-level merchants and entrepreneurs. Difference in ONDC vs E-commerce players The major difference between the two is that the merchant and the customer can collaborate together irrespective of how one is present digitally. For example, a merchant might not be listed on any platform like Amazon, Flipkart or Dunzo but still can avail the services of Dunzo to send grocery to the customer. In fact, it is possible that the merchant have never availed the services of any digital platform. Another difference is that while ordering from e-commerce players, everything needs to happen on their platform. But using ONDC, offline merchants can easily offer their own forms of support and just use digital platforms for transactions and logistics. Summing Up The ONDC platform is much easy to use. Vendors can onboard easily. There is cost transparency. It will demolish the monopoly of the big e-commerce players who play by their own terms. They give all the facilities to customers but sometimes ignore their sellers. ONDC will bring all the merchants at the same level and will give more value to the customers by increasing the number of listings for them. In case you liked this piece, give a thumbs up. You can connect to me on Twitter too.

name: testerops
headline: One of the most important professional qualities that you can have today is the ability to woo the target audience like investors, your team members with a perfect presentation. A nice and well prepared presentation along with killer presentation skills will make your work a lot easier in many scena
content: One of the most important professional qualities that you can have today is the ability to woo the target audience like investors, your team members with a perfect presentation. A nice and well prepared presentation along with killer presentation skills will make your work a lot easier in many scenarios. I am always looking to hone my presentation skills and like to work on it at any point of day. So I always keep on looking for nice articles and people's suggestion on key points which needs to focused more while presenting. And believe me, from a shy person, wary of giving a simple presentation, I have transformed into a confident person, who is not afraid of speaking in front of an audience today. Yesterday, I was browsing Quora, and I found a perfect answer given by Balaji Vishwanathan , on understanding how you would hone your presentation skills. If you go through the answer, he has given a proper, detailed analysis of how to approach and deliver a kick-ass presentation. Before the preparation Who: Understand the target. What does an average person sitting in the auditorium look like? Feel them, imagine them, draw them. What level of competency do they have in the subject you are going to present? Tailor the content to your audience. Never try to go over their heads or beneath their feet. Once you start visualizing the audience and get them into their heads, you can make an emotional bond with them. Why: Understand your motive. Why are you presenting? What are you planning to achieve after the presentation? Is it to attract investors? Is it to convince a scientific audience about the validity of your work? The presentation is just the marketing of your content and cannot be a replacement for your main content (a detailed deck & metrics in case of fund raising & a paper in case of a research presentation). The presentation is one of the weapons that should lead you to that strategic objective. What: Understand the context. What is the broad context of your presentation. Is it a part of a demo day? Is it part of an academic conference? Is it a company meeting? Is it a fund raising event for a charity? Is it a product demo? The context should drive your content and intent. Understand the Bikini rule of life - Reveal enough and conceal enough to spark interest. Most of us have the temptation to dump all the stuff we got into the poor little Powerpoint. That leads to intimidation and confusion. The goal of the presentation should be to spark that interest in your work so that your target comes towards you. In essence it is a conversation starter by gaining their attention. The Marketing Mindset When you are presenting, you are actually marketing [to eventually lead to a "sale" - of whatever you are attempting]. Get into that mindset. You can never sell someone an important idea through a single shot. You need go through a series of stages in the process of them buying your idea. First get them to be aware of your product, generate an interest and eventually lead them to process that leads them to "purchase". Your presentation should do the first two stages below. Preparing for your presentation The powerpoint deck is not a handout . Don't be that guy handing out irrelevant printouts of your powerpoint. Prepare a document handout prepared through a document creator like MS Word or InDesign. The powerpoint deck should not be a readable one . Certainly not a printable one. [If they are reading, they are not listening to you]. It should be to connect. To get your audience to be interested in you. No more than 7-10 words. Once the audience like your idea, they should have the handout to read more and then come to you for a much detailed walk through. Prepare a script. Powerpoint deck is not your cheatsheet to read from. Don't rest on that. Have a strong script and use the projection to complement what you say. When you have finished rehearsing, rehearse hard. Whenever I present without rehearsing, the result shows immediately in the audience [boredom]. Get to the empty stage. Before an important presentation, get to the stage when the whole place is empty. Pace the stage and let the physical world consume you. Feel at home and let the environment absorb you. Do a dry run. During one of my recent presentations, I didn't do a tech dry run. Not surprisingly the tech melted down and there was precious minutes lost. Make sure the technology doesn't fail you. Be very comfortable with the clothes you are going to wear. You should feel those clothes are an extension of your body. I have a favorite suit I bought 7 years ago and I don't wear any of my other suits for the most important presentations. I take it ceremonially and feel like a knight in his armor. That suit provides the cloak of invincibility. Once I'm in, I feel all the good omens from the past presentations come in and push me and give the confidence. When I'm in my favorite suit, I feel I can convince anyone in the world. During the presentation Have a good look at the audience and your preparation should have made you feel very close to that target. After you get to the stage and have setup your mike, don't start talking immediately. Pause a couple of seconds taking a good strong look with a strong smile [you can see that great leaders always do that before they start their speech]. That is when you are conveying you can be trusted. That brief 2-3 seconds can be very crucial. Disarm and charm the audience with mild self-deprecation . Get your first joke on yourself. Let the audience laugh. While I was once presenting to a group of rich southerners in Nashville, I made fun of my accent. The audience were smiling the whole time as I turned by weakness into an advantage [they were more attentive due to my accent, after that point]. I opened with this slide on 2 different occassions [both very important] and on both occassions, the audience burst out laughing & remembered the presentation. A designer friend crafted this deck for me. Don't turn your back on the audience and look to move a bit. A body language expert once coached on the right way to move & make the audience trust. Coming forward conveys trust. So, when you are conveying your big idea or getting to the ask, move a few inches forward. That little movement forward can send a lot of subtle cues. Going back can send messages of dishonestly. Thus, avoid moving back [unless you are taking a joke on you] and always make a small movement forward - and make that movement so subtle that the audience doesn't even know you are walking towards them. Also avoid showing the back of your hand or the back of the body - those all increases distrust. Master your pauses. This is the hardest thing to do for non-professionals. Masters of drama know when to pause to give that impact. After your big idea got to the screen, wait a second or two to give that dramatic effect. Let the audience absorb the drama. Keep your basics correct - making eye contact with a chunk of the audience, changing your tones a bit. As a parting note, give the presentation its due importance. Give the audience their due respect. A presentation can change your whole life. Thus, take it seriously and do the homework.

name: amitandani
headline: Recently, completing the NeuroLeadership Institute's "Team: The Neuroscience of Psychological Safety" course powerfully reaffirmed a critical truth for leaders: Psychological safety isn't merely a "soft skill" - it's a definitive strategic advantage.
content: Recently, completing the NeuroLeadership Institute's "Team: The Neuroscience of Psychological Safety" course powerfully reaffirmed a critical truth for leaders: Psychological safety isn't merely a "soft skill" - it's a definitive strategic advantage. High-performing teams don't just avoid conflict; they thrive because leaders deliberately cultivate an environment where everyone feels secure enough to speak up, challenge norms, experiment, and learn openly. This is the true genesis of innovation. Fundamentally, psychological safety empowers teams to: â¤ Share diverse perspectives without hesitation. â¤ Challenge assumptions, sparking new ideas. â¤ View mistakes as invaluable learning opportunities. â¤ Contribute confidently, regardless of communication style. As leaders, our actions set the precedent. Our behavior directly dictates whether our teams feel empowered to think boldly or constrained by hesitation. Three Leadership Habits Driving Psychological Safety: âœ… 1 - Set the Stage - Clarity & Shared Purpose â¤ Define "Us": Establish team identity and collective purpose. â¤ Frame Impact: Articulate the significance and value of our work. â¤ Proactive Planning: Anticipate and prepare for challenges effectively. âœ… 2 - Invite Participation - Amplify Every Voice â¤ Lead with Humility: Demonstrate an openness to not having all answers. â¤ Streamline Input: Provide diverse, easy channels for contribution. â¤ Spark Curiosity: Actively encourage fresh perspectives and exploration. âœ… 3 - Respond Thoughtfully - Reinforce Openness â¤ Validate Contributions: Acknowledge and affirm inputs to build confidence. â¤ Cultivate Constructive Debate: Normalize respectful challenges and disagreements. â¤ Drive Forward Thinking: Elevate ideas to uncover breakthrough innovations. Consistent application of these habits builds teams that collaborate with unwavering confidence and innovate with genuine courage. A sincere thank you to DBS Bank and DBS Tech India for championing continuous learning and enabling us to integrate these crucial principles into our leadership practices. It is our collective responsibility as leaders to forge environments where individuals feel safe to think boldly, speak openly, and continuously evolveâ€”because this is precisely where groundbreaking innovation truly takes root. #PsychologicalSafety #LeadershipDevelopment #GrowwithDBSTech

name: abidalee
headline: The world is constantly evolving around us. Things change every day.
content: The world is constantly evolving around us. Things change every day. New trends emerge regularly and become the â€˜talk of the townâ€™. Everybody jumps onto the bandwagon. Just in the 20th century many new careers evolved. There was a time when manufacturing was at the top, then the banking, medicine, engineering, and law took the place, and with the advent of the information age and with the growing computing power, every industry is adopting computers as it has become necessary. The 21st century is so called â€˜the Information ageâ€™ but for how long? Would it become just like other careers due to the saturation and then we will â€˜inventâ€™ another career? Many people get MBAs hoping to get into executive roles but many end up doing normal accounting, finance, banking or marketing. Some like to pursue performing arts, while others like liberal arts. The point is, there are too many career choices, donâ€™t limit yourself, look around, find what you truly like and believe in, and then pursue it with passion and dedication, but do not just follow the crowd. IT seems to be one of the major career choices for many these days but IT is not just writing computer programs. It is like medical field, too many options to choose from. Not everyone is and should be a technical person. Computer is not just about writing programs, it is much more than that. There are many areas in IT like thought leadership, sales, marketing, animations, graphics, games, hardware, software and many more to choose from. Donâ€™t get confused by the buzz words like â€˜cloudâ€™, â€˜big dataâ€™, and the like. As long as you know the basic principles, everything remains the same. Just because you are studying computers and donâ€™t like programming and are not good at it, it does not belittle you in anyway. There are too many options to choose from because â€˜the world is your oyster.â€™ But yes, â€˜constantly reinvent yourselfâ€™ and keep learning new things as â€˜moving water never goes stale.â€™ Web: http://parwaaztheflight.org Facebook: www.facebook.com/ParwaazTheFlight Twitter: https://twitter.com/ParwazTheFlight Parwaaz Intro: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjceJlDS2g4 Let's 'light a candle', the candle of 'kindness', the candle of 'hope', the candle of 'love and affection', and the candle of 'knowledge and wisdom', to 'fight the darkness', the darkness within and around.

name: souhamdash
headline: Not every AI agent deserves your attention.
content: Not every AI agent deserves your attention. ğ—¢ğ—½ğ—²ğ—»ğ—–ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜„ earned mine. ğŸ¦ Yesterday, I installed OpenClaw on my local machine. Not as a casual tech experiment. As a product hypothesis. After a couple of years of building AI-first products, you develop an instinct for separating signal from noise. Most â€œAI agentsâ€ today are still chatbots with better storytelling. OpenClaw felt different, and the reason becomes obvious once you look at how itâ€™s designed. At its core, it cleanly separates: * Brain â†’ reasoning models * Hands â†’ executable skills * Memory â†’ persistent, human-readable state (Markdown, not mystery blobs) This distinction is not cosmetic. Itâ€™s the difference between rigid workflow automation and outcome-driven delegation, where you describe intent and the system constructs the pipeline. Thatâ€™s a meaningful architectural shift. I spent time stress-testing multi-model orchestration (Claude for depth, GPT for speed, local models for sensitive work), modular skills defined in plain English, persistent file-based memory, cross-platform task execution, and sandboxed security boundaries. This feels less like prompt engineering and more like designing a system that can actually do work. Itâ€™s not polished. Installation friction is real, the trust layer is still maturing, and the UX assumes technical fluency. But the latest release shipping a malicious-skill scanner tells me the team understands the real adoption blockers and is moving fast. This isnâ€™t about being perfect. Itâ€™s about proving the paradigm. Weâ€™re watching the shift from â€œğ—”ğ—œ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—³ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—²â€ ğ˜ğ—¼ â€œğ—”ğ—œ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—².â€ OpenClaw makes that shift tangible. #OpenClaw #AIProductManagement #GenerativeAI #AIAgents #TechStrategy #AgenticAI

name: tripti-srivastava-28958416a
headline: Ever wondered why PINK screams "girl power" everywhere?
content: Ever wondered why PINK screams "girl power" everywhere? Did we girls/women pick it, or did someone hand it to us on a pink platter? This question's been buzzing in my head for years, looking at gender reveal parties (blue balloons for boys, pink for girls), family baby showers drowning in pink gifts, and ads pushing the vibe. Fun fact from history though: Back in the early 1900s, pink was for boys (think fiery red vibes), blue for girls. But mid-20th century marketers flipped the script with clever campaigns, store guides, and Barbie dolls, making pink the girl color. Baby girls get pink dreamcatchers, frocks, and toys from day one! it's the world serving it up, not always our choice! (Not Mine atleast). Here we are in 2026, and it's still the same old tune: Relatives popping blue/pink balloons for newborns (rainbow gets ignored), funny-not-funny videos of dads sulking over Barbie bags vs cheerful with video games ("Dude, let her pick: FIFA or dolls?"), and few nonprofits (sorry but not sorry!) slapping "Pink" on everything women-related. Pink Toilets? Government! Really? (The ladies' sign works fine!) I was introduced to PS5, Hot Wheels, punching bags, and COD pretty late by my male cousins, friends, and husband, but now I absolutely love them! And boys can love pink too! Again, it's 2026 and STILL! Not starting a fight, just sharing a lightbulb moment. Am I solo in my circle on this? Your thoughts? Nudging ads, brands, gov programs, nonprofits, friends, and family toward choice, not checkboxes! What do you think? Ministry of Women & Child Development Procter & Gamble Swachh Bharat Mission Grameen EstÃ©e Lauder #LetUsChoose #RealTalk #MarketingNudge #LetKidsChoose

name: testerops
headline: Here is an excellent post I found on Quora, posted by Oliver Emberton. Our brains are the most bug ridden pieces of junk since Internet Explorer.
content: Here is an excellent post I found on Quora, posted by Oliver Emberton. Our brains are the most bug ridden pieces of junk since Internet Explorer. To replicate one common bug, try telling your brain to â€œgo to the gymâ€. Most brains will respond by updating their Facebook status, and watching cat videos. This is not the desired behaviour. Fortunately Iâ€™ve developed a fix. Let me just explain how the whole human brain works first. This code is a mess Looking at our brain, itâ€™s clear it was developed by a team of ten thousand monkeys with a serious drinking problem. You know, like Windows 8. The brain is event-driven , which is to say it does almost nothing until an event occurs, and then it responds to the event. Your hand gets hot, you pull it back. Your stomach rumbles, you look for food. Unfortunately there are a lot of events. There are events for shiny objects coming into view, or for scary monsters, or for boobs â€“ actually, there are 856 different events for boobs, but I digress â€“ and all of these events are firing in our brain and competing for our limited processing ability. Too late the developers realised this would leave us bouncing between distractions like a cat chasing a laser pointer, and they hacked in a priority system. Unfortunately, our priority system is a bit pants: the default priority for sitting down is higher than the priority for working out. But wait! Weâ€™re smarter than â€“ ooh, a squirrel Donâ€™t we have some kind of clever, conscious brain though? The part that does math and plays chess and copies Sallyâ€™s homework? Well, yes. But that part is event driven too, which is to say itâ€™s not on all the time. It turns out our brains were optimised for energy efficiency, and they only turn on their CPU (Consciousness Processing Unit) when absolutely necessary. If youâ€™ve ever realised youâ€™ve been driving for an hour and hadnâ€™t even noticed, that was your consciousness going into Standby Mode. Itâ€™s your consciousness that tells you to exercise, even if you donâ€™t want to, because it can see the long term benefits are greater than the short term pain. And when itâ€™s in control, you do so. But consciousness demands a lot of power. When your mental battery is low, itâ€™s easily overpowered out by higher priorities, like playing Hearthstone or squeezing a particularly awkward spot. The bug fix Weâ€™re going to add a new event of our own to fix things. Non-programmers might call this a â€˜habitâ€™. Our new event is triggered by a transition . For example, if you wake up, thatâ€™s a transition. Arrive at your desk â€“ thatâ€™s a transition. Arrive home â€“ thatâ€™s a transition. Itâ€™s at the transition that our behaviour is most likely to be hijacked by the highest priority event that happens to be in our brain at the time. If youâ€™ve arrived home, chances are that event is â€œIâ€™m knackeredâ€ and youâ€™ll fall onto the sofa. We need to stop that. Donâ€™t worry if youâ€™re not fluent in Brain Programming (B#) â€“ just remember three words: â€œNo. Right. Now.â€ Letâ€™s break it down: â€œNoâ€ Firstly, we need to interrupt all other events. Thereâ€™s a trick for overpowering mental distractions, and thatâ€™s to make your intention insanely simple . No is about as simple an intention as you can get. No means simply reject everything . If you want to check Facebook, the answer is no. If someone is asking you if you have 5 minutes, the answer is no. If this will piss someone off, itâ€™s still no. Donâ€™t complicate this with exceptions. Exceptions will happen anyway â€“ if your house is on fire, primal instincts will take over. But 99.9% of the time, in our comfortable modern lives, the greatest danger to you is that you live by your outdated survival impulses. Start by saying no to everything. You might worry that by declining everyone and everything youâ€™ll become some kind of sociopathic robot. Youâ€™ll still have time for those distractions later. Tell people that . The trick is to get done what matters first . â€œRightâ€ Now ask yourself what is the one â€˜rightâ€™ thing you should be doing now. I did not say three things . There can be only one. You shouldnâ€™t need to think about this much, because your conscious brain should already have decided for you the night before: itâ€™s usually the one thing you want to do all the time, but never find time for. A crucial distinction here is importance versus urgency . The most important things in life â€“ like eating healthy â€“ are rarely urgent. And our brainâ€™s buggy events are great at dealing with urgent things â€“ like the phone ringing â€“ all by themselves. So when given the choice, choose importance over urgency . It makes the most difference in the long run. â€œNowâ€ Start doing the right thing immediately. Not after youâ€™ve checked your email â€“ immediately . Donâ€™t give yourself time to even think about it , just start . Starting is always the hardest part; the very inertia which makes something hard to start can make it equally hard to stop. This simple fix works because when you transition from one place to another, your brain is unusually receptive to events. It needs to decide on a new course of action, and once it chooses one it tends to stick to it. Unfortunately we tend to make stupid decisions at transitions, because we donâ€™t think about them: Interrupt your transitions with the right choices, and youâ€™ll find yourself doing what matters far, far more often: Just remember: â€œNo. Right. Now.â€ Three short words to program a life changing habit. Here is the link to the complete answer- with awesome images : http://abetterlife.quora.com/How-to-debug-your-brain

name: swatiichandak
headline: Swatii Chandakâ€™s Post
content: As I swayed with the mustard fields, a thought kept returning to me, leadership reminds me of Farming... A farmer understands that growth does not come from giving equal attention to every patch of land, it comes from patiently nurturing what carries the promise of a good harvest. When focus shifts toward distractions rather than nurturing potential, the healthiest plants quietly lose their strengthâ€¦ ...and sometimes, they are replanted where the soil supports their growth. A farmer eventually turns to new land when the soil no longer nurtures the crops that are ready to grow. In the same way, people who work with purpose know when to raise their voice for what truly matters, and when to remain quiet and let their work speak for itself. They continue with sincerity, hoping the environment aligns with vision but when meaning fades, they move forward with grace. Perhaps leadership lies in recognising what deserves nurturing, what needs direction, and what should not distract us from collective growth.

name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
headline: Building AI Agents That Actually Learn From Experience
content: Building AI Agents That Actually Learn From Experience Most AI agents today are static. They execute tasks, return results, and forget everything by the next session. But what if agents could genuinely learn and improve over time? I've been exploring a continual learning framework built on a simple but powerful loop: ACT â†’ RECORD â†’ REFLECT â†’ LEARN The agent doesn't just complete tasksâ€”it captures every action, analyzes its own performance, and extracts reusable knowledge. This happens through three distinct learning mechanisms: 1. Memory Learning The agent remembers facts, user preferences, and behavioral patterns. No more repeating yourself across sessions. 2. Prompt Optimization Through self-reflection, the agent identifies what worked and refines its own instructions. It literally rewrites how it thinks. 3. Skill Creation Successful multi-step workflows get extracted into reusable skills (SOPs). What once required step-by-step guidance becomes a single command. The key insight: learning isn't a separate training phase. It's woven into the operational loop. Every interaction is an opportunity to improve. This mirrors how humans develop expertiseâ€”through deliberate practice and reflection, not just repetition. The gap between "AI assistant" and "AI colleague" isn't more parameters. It's memory, self-improvement, and accumulated skill. Curious to hear from others building in this spaceâ€”how are you approaching agent learning and long-term memory?

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Itâ€™s really great that you have decided to work on one of the most prominent DI frameworks of today. Before going into the content flow, I will give a short introduction.
content: Itâ€™s really great that you have decided to work on one of the most prominent DI frameworks of today. Before going into the content flow, I will give a short introduction. So, what is Spring? The Spring Framework is an application framework and inversion of control container for the Java platform. The framework's core features can be used by any Java application, but there are extensions for building web applications on top of the Java EE platform. How should you study Spring? Every technology is better understood when you are clear with its concepts. So, I will recommend you to study Spring, dividing the curriculum in nine different modules as below. Introduction: Difference between Spring and EJB, Java Beans, Factory Design Pattern, Spring Architecture, Spring Modules, New Features of Spring, Installation, Directory Structure, Spring Namespaces Aspect Oriented Programming: Definition, Advantages, AOP Terminologies, Advice Types, Static and Dynamic Pointcuts, Proxy Based AOP, Declarative Based AOP, Annotation Based AOP Minimizing Spring Configuration: Explicit Wiring, Autowiring, Annotation Based Wiring, Autodiscovery, Java Based Configuration Spring Middle Layer: Spring DAO, Template Callback Design Pattern, Spring JDBC, Spring with Hibernate, Programmative and Declarative Transactions with differences, Propagation Behavior, Isolation Levels Spring MVC: Introduction, Spring MVC Architecture, HandlerMapping, ViewResolver, Controller Classes, MVC Workflow, Annotation Driven Controller, Form Binding and Processing, Validations Spring with REST API Spring Security Spring with STRUTS Integration Spring Boot Once you are thorough with all these above topics, you are all set in Spring. Hope by now, you have figured out how to plan your Spring studiesâ€¦ Enjoy Learning!!! Happy Coding!!!

name: abidalee
headline: For last several months I have seen these and similar hashtags, never in my wildest imaginations I had thought that I would be using them myself. I read many stories over the months, some based on science, others based on conspiracy theories.
content: For last several months I have seen these and similar hashtags, never in my wildest imaginations I had thought that I would be using them myself. I read many stories over the months, some based on science, others based on conspiracy theories. The former I found to be useful and full of hope, and the later, full of ignorance. I say this because of my first-hand experience with #covid19. The year 2020 ended with bad news for our family, my father was tested positive on December 31st. The year 2021 brought another bad news, i.e. my mother was tested positive on Jan 1st (followed by several of my siblings getting the virus). We were hopeful because both my parents (and the entire family) were fighting it. The battle started at home, moved quickly to the hospital, and within a few days we lost our dear mother yesterday to this deadly disease. It is hard to believe that just a few days ago I was speaking with her on the phone, and she was full of life and hope, and now she is not among us. She was a very strong woman and fought till the last minute. She was fully determined to beat it but unfortunately she lost the battle and the virus took her life. All the recent and advanced medications couldnâ€™t save her. My father and other family members are recuperating and we as a family continue to fight this battle (hence need all the prayers). I wanted to take a moment and remind everyone that please do not listen to the ignorant people who think of #covid19 as a hoax. It is a deadly disease, from speaking with my mother on phone a few days ago to seeing her losing her battle just in a matter of days proves one thing to me that this disease is NOT a joke, and it is not going anywhere until it has done enough damage. You need to protect yourself and your loved ones. The easiest thing is to â€˜wear a mask!â€™. I also want to mention that we often focus on the patients and forget the caretakers, who are the #realheroes, and by caretakers, I donâ€™t mean the medical professionals (yes they are indeed heroes), but I mean the family members, who are fighting the battle alongside their loved ones. My mother has always been my hero and source of strength and inspiration, but today, my even a bigger hero is #Neelum, our little sister, who did not give up till the last minute, who was rushing from ward to ward, pharmacy to pharmacy, 24x7, without any sleep or even caring for her own health. She is the #realwonderwoman of the family because she was the #lastonestanding while everyone else got the virus. She, just like our mother, was fully determined to defeat the virus but it did eventually take away our mother. All power to you #Neelum and thanks for being the source of hope and strength for the entire family during these trying times

name: stephenthomashiggins
headline: Thinking about vibe coding your own version of HubSpot?
content: Thinking about vibe coding your own version of HubSpot? Hereâ€™s why it might be a good idea. Youâ€™re technical. Youâ€™re efficient. AI can scaffold a clean CRM in a weekend. No bloat. No subscription fees. Fully customized to your motion. On the surface, it makes sense. Until you remember: a CRM isnâ€™t a database with stages. Itâ€™s your: â€¢ System of record â€¢ Forecasting engine â€¢ Revenue governance layer â€¢ Attribution model â€¢ Automation hub â€¢ Integration spine â€¢ Compliance surface And it has to work at scale. Vibe coding works when the blast radius is small â€” internal tools, workflow prototypes, lightweight automation, reporting overlays. If it breaks, nothing fundamental breaks. A CRM is different. The failure cost compounds over time: â€¢ Data integrity degrades. â€¢ Forecast accuracy erodes. â€¢ Integrations become technical debt. â€¢ Security and permissions become your problem. â€¢ Adoption becomes a behavioral battle. Most homegrown CRMs donâ€™t fail immediately. They fail at scale. And hereâ€™s the real issue: opportunity cost. If youâ€™re a founder or revenue leader, your leverage isnâ€™t writing CRUD logic. Itâ€™s improving win rates, cycle time, ACV, talent density, and forecast precision. Every hour spent maintaining infrastructure is an hour not spent increasing revenue throughput. Platforms like HubSpot outperform custom builds not because theyâ€™re perfect â€” but because they compound: â€¢ Institutionalized GTM best practices â€¢ Reliability under scale â€¢ Deep integrations â€¢ Continuous iteration without engineering lift â€¢ Board-level credibility in forecasting The trap is ego disguised as efficiency: â€œWe can build it cleaner.â€ Maybe. For a while. But youâ€™ll eventually pay in technical debt, migration pain, or both. Vibe code the experiments. Configure the infrastructure. Your CRM isnâ€™t a side project. Itâ€™s your revenue operating system.

name: ybernstein
headline: Process is a skeleton. Culture is the muscles that attach to that skeleton.
content: Process is a skeleton. Culture is the muscles that attach to that skeleton. Without muscles to move it, the skeleton is inert and useless. Without a skeleton to attach to, the muscles are an amorphous and undirected mass. It is easy to assume that an organisation lacking in process will be fixed simply by the addition of and adherence to that process. I made that assumption, but it turns out to be wrong. Process needs to be introduced in tandem with a concerted initiative to evolve the culture such that the process becomes embedded within the culture. I've spoken about code review before. Code review was one of my favourite things about working as a software engineer at Google. When I joined Flare, there was no code review, so I thought the fix was easy: introduce code review! And I did. But although this was necessary, it turned out not to be sufficient. Code reviews felt more like a rubber stamp than robust forums for discussion and upholding the values and norms of software quality. We had the skeleton, but without the muscle code review seemed more like an impediment than something really valuable. Only with a lot of hard work alongside the team have we started to develop a culture of code review. The stronger the culture, the more value we get.

Itâ€™s harder than most people think. â€“ Integrated cloud stacks are starting to win over fully custom builds once complexity kicks in. â€“ AI cost is becoming a real line item. Itâ€™s no longer magic. Itâ€™s infrastructure. â€“ In Australia, region and compliance genuinely shape architecture decisions. What Iâ€™m noticing is the conversation is getting more practical. Architecture. Constraints. Costs. Compliance. Curious what others are seeing inside their teams right now?

name: ybernstein
headline: One of the things that excites me about working in technology is the subtle but deep interplay between technology, product, and market. Making the right decision on a matter as seemingly technical as how to set up indexes on a database table requires an understanding of how the product is used, and
content: One of the things that excites me about working in technology is the subtle but deep interplay between technology, product, and market. Making the right decision on a matter as seemingly technical as how to set up indexes on a database table requires an understanding of how the product is used, and what the key drivers of the business are. What are the most common patterns of access to the data going to be? Which queries sit behind latency-sensitive conversion drivers and must be optimised at any expense? And so on. At the same time, product and business decisions cannot be made well without meaningful technical input. A particular product decision might be really easy to implement, or it might be very hard. Is doubling the number of events being logged simply a matter of adding a couple of lines of code? Or does it involve refactoring a complex module to remove a performance bottleneck? In the latter case, perhaps a simple workaround (shard to two different logs) would obviate the need for a huge amount of work. Software development is an endless series of decisions and tradeoffs, large and small. Attempting to centralise this decision-making with product management or engineering leadership results in disastrous micromanagement. Most likely, many of the decisions are taken by developers anyway---but without the necessary context and thus suboptimally. The only way to build great products is to empower developers to act like product owners. What does this mean? At the most basic level this requires that developers have a good understanding of the product they are building. Software development takes place within a broader context. If you deny software developers the context they need to make good technical decisions, the result will be much like an historical novel written by somebody with no knowledge of the relevant period in history; perhaps satisfactory in superficial form, but filled with incorrect details and misapprehensions. It is imperative that developers are both expected and afforded the opportunity to understand their users and customers---and indeed to think of them as their users and customers. Beyond understanding, a true developer-as-product-owner mentality means constructively questioning the product and making suggestions about how the product (as opposed to just the software) could be built. As a technical leader, I often see myself as the yin to a Product Manager's yang. Both of us are in a sense paid to think about how to build a good product; but whereas the PMs job is to think expansively and creatively about what could be, the technical lead's job is to keep that vision of the future grounded to realities of technology and limited resources. But I hate being a bottleneck, so a much better way of scaling this dynamic is for all developers to take this approach. At Google, one of the dimensions along which a developer's performance was measured was the impact of their work. When this new rubric was first introduced, I was quite unhappy with it. I even wrote a long internal blog post called "impact considered harmful" that argued it was unfair to judge a developer's performance based on something that was in many cases beyond their control. As time passed, though, I realised that having impact as part of my job description was actually very empowering. If I'm required to optimise my impact, that means that all sorts of things are now part of my job! This realisation instantly made me feel more like a product owner, because bad product decisions or strategic indecisiveness had the possibility to drag down my performance score. Ultimately thinking like a product owner means caring about the end result, not just about an intermediate output. Whether you are in a small startup (where this comes naturally) or a hulking multinational (where it takes real effort to instill the culture) there is no doubt that having everybody keeping their eye on what their organisation is actually trying to achieve leads to more accountability and better decision-making across the board.

name: stephaniehillsphd
headline: You donâ€™t need more credentials. You need more clarity.
content: You donâ€™t need more credentials. You need more clarity . Thatâ€™s what actually moves your career forward. ğŸš€ When I first started my business, I felt completely stuck. I was running the business, trying different things, juggling ideasâ€”but I wasnâ€™t making the kind of progress I wanted. I had the skills. The drive. But I was lacking clarity , direction , and momentum . Thatâ€™s when I found Think and Grow Rich by Napoleon Hill. I didnâ€™t expect a book from 1937 to shift how I thought about my entire career. But it did. ğŸ And it started with Chapter 1â€” Desire . Maybe you're in that place right now. ğŸ’ª Youâ€™re ambitious. ğŸ’ª Smart. ğŸ’ª Capable. But...youâ€™re second-guessing your next move. Youâ€™re not sure what the right role isâ€”or if the one you're in is even aligned. ğŸš« Youâ€™re busy, but not fulfilled. ğŸš« Moving, but not advancing. And itâ€™s not your fault . Most career advice tells you to follow the next shiny title, build your rÃ©sumÃ©, or chase whateverâ€™s trending in the job market. Youâ€™re told to "do more," â€œbe realistic,â€ and â€œwait your turn.â€ But thatâ€™s the problem. ğŸš« Weâ€™ve been trained to work harderâ€¦ not to think deeper. ğŸš« Weâ€™ve been taught to fit into a roleâ€¦ not to design a life. âš¡ï¸ The moment I stopped asking what should I do? and started asking what do I truly desire? Thatâ€™s when everything shifted. Not just in my business, but in how I showed upâ€”in my energy, my confidence, and the kind of clients and opportunities I attracted. You donâ€™t grow your career by doing more. You grow by getting clear on what you want. ğŸ”¥ Overview: The 13 Principles of Think and Grow Rich ğŸ”¥ Napoleon Hill studied hundreds of the most successful people of his time and distilled their success into 13 principles . This book isnâ€™t just about money. Itâ€™s about becoming the kind of person who creates success intentionallyâ€”with clarity, purpose, and beliefâ€”for your life, career, and financial freedom. The 13 Steps to Riches (and your dream life) are Desire Faith Auto-Suggestion Specialized Knowledge Imagination Organized Planning Decision Persistence Power of the Mastermind The Mystery of Sex Transmutation The Subconscious Mind The Brain The Sixth Sense Each of these applies to your career journey , and Iâ€™ll be walking through all of themâ€”one article at a time. ğŸ Letâ€™s start at the foundation: Step 1: Desire â€“ The Starting Point of Career Success ğŸ”¥ Hill calls Desire the starting point of all achievementâ€”not hope, not wish, not luck. A burning desire. Crystal-clear, all-in, uncompromising. In your career, that means this: You have to know what you want before you can attract it, create it, or get promoted into it. Most people skip this part. They stay vague: â€œI just want something better.â€ But vague desires produce vague results. Hill outlines six steps to turn desire into results. Letâ€™s expand on those and apply them directly to your career: âœ… 10 Career-Driven Ways to Apply Napoleon Hillâ€™s Principle of Desire: 1ï¸âƒ£ Get specific. What exactly do you want? Promotion? Pivot? Leadership role? Your own business? Name it. 2ï¸âƒ£ Attach meaning to it. Why does this matter to you personally ? What would it change in your life? The moment you attach deep emotion to your visionâ€”it becomes a MUST. And when itâ€™s a MUST, your brain finds the way. 3ï¸âƒ£ Decide what youâ€™ll give in return. Time? Focus? Learning? Growth? This is about investment, not sacrifice. It is time to invest in yourself. To commit fully. 4ï¸âƒ£ Set a target date. When will this happen? â€œSomedayâ€ is not a strategy. Imagine it was a year from now and you are looking back at the past year. 5ï¸âƒ£ Create a career statement. â€œI will become a Director of Engineering by July 2025 and lead a high-impact global team.â€ I print mine out and put it on my vision board. Read it out loud daily. 6ï¸âƒ£ Visualize it. See yourself doing the work. Feeling fulfilled. Living the life that aligns. Imagine the freedom it brings. 7ï¸âƒ£ Write a simple plan. A roadmap that includes the next 3 actions you can take. Take daily massive imperfect action. 8ï¸âƒ£ Cut the noise. Remove one obligation that doesn't align with your desire. Reclaim that energy. I like to call this my "not to do" list. What can you eliminate? 9ï¸âƒ£ Surround yourself with belief. Join communities, follow leaders, and get mentors who reinforce whatâ€™s possible. Remember, you are who you surround yourself with. ğŸ”Ÿ Refuse to settle. Desire is only powerful when you back it with action and commitmentâ€”even when doubt shows up. ğŸš€ Desire isnâ€™t just the first step in growing rich and having the career and life of your dreamsâ€” Itâ€™s the first step in becoming fully aligned. Ready for the next step? In the next article, Iâ€™ll break down Faith â€”what Hill calls the power behind your beliefâ€”and how to use it to power every career move with confidence. ğŸ”¥ Until then, donâ€™t chase titles. Chase what sets you on fire. ğŸ”¥ â™» Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. â• Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # leadershipdevelopment #worklifebalance #careeralignment #careerIlove #thinkandgrowrich #desire #dreamlife

name: kpowerinfinity
headline: Seventeen Years
content: Seventeen Years Today Capillary Technologies goes public. Seventeen years since three kids fresh out of college decided to start something in the wreckage of 2008. I wasn't there for the second half.. the harder half. Aneesh steered this ship through storms I can only imagine. I'm grateful beyond words. What I remember most isn't the milestones. It's the texture of those early days. Merchants in Kolkata who humored us when we had nothing. Durga Puja 2008, camped outside police headquarters chasing traffic updates. Pan IIT at IIT Madras where our scrappy SMS service caught fire. That first angel check of â‚¹15 lakhs from IIT Kharagpur that we paid back in crores. We had no idea what we were doing. Just energy, naivety, and this strange refusal to think small. Then Aditya Birla and Future Group said yes. Right after Lehman fell. I still don't know why they trusted us. The apartment in CV Raman Nagar with no water during the day. Chai walks in BTM Layout with Shubh , Abhilash , Prakhar , Piyush .. trying to figure out if we were building something or just fooling ourselves. Then loyalty took off. That first campaignâ€”â‚¹11 lakhs in incremental sales, one weekend, fully attributed. That's when we saw it. A chance meeting with Karthee at CCD led to the Qualcomm QPrize. We were shocked when we won. The business grew, but we stayed scrappy. That tiny hotel in Dadar because it was cheapest. The Bangalore home-office. The Gurgaon apartment where Ajay held the fort. Holed up in Bur Dubai searching for product-market fit. The exhilaration when Sequoia Capital and Norwest bet on us, alongside angels like Rajan , Venkat , KS , and Harminder . But what I really remember are the crazy things. Flooding someone in Gujarat with hundreds of thousands of texts. The new hire who nearly wiped our database on day oneâ€”later led all of engineering (take a bow, Piyush ). Anant building a POS system on an Excel sheet to close a deal. Sujatha , our first female hire, making sure our office was no longer a dorm room. Building loyalty systems where internet barely workedâ€”the magic of "nightly sync." We were pirates, not professionals. That's what made it magic. Like humans, companies find their early years most thrilling. The teenage years? Brutal. But at seventeen, she's finally readyâ€”scarred, wiser, infinitely stronger. We remember our failures more than our wins. We carry the scar tissue. But today, we celebrate. What a journey, Capillary family. What a journey.

name: ybernstein
headline: I'm just starting my fourth week at Flare, a two-year-old startup with about 30 people, after a ten year career at Google which, with north of 40,000 employees and a market cap of half a trillion dollars, is definitively not a startup. Flare is awesome, by the way.
content: I'm just starting my fourth week at Flare , a two-year-old startup with about 30 people, after a ten year career at Google which, with north of 40,000 employees and a market cap of half a trillion dollars, is definitively not a startup. Flare is awesome, by the way. A great team, great business plan, lots of interesting challenges, and a real openness to all perspectives on the best way to achieve our goals. Anyway. As part of getting started I decided to share some early observations about the software development process at the company. One of my slides had this diagram: What I had observed was that every company is on a journey, and for every step on that journey there is a "right" amount of process to have in place. Good processes (e.g. documenting what you do, or having approval checklists for product launches) allow your organisation to operate at a larger scale, build higher-quality and more complex systems, reduce risk, and increase predictability. Well-considered and well-implemented processes support teams and individuals in doing their jobs. However, processes come at a cost in terms of raw productivity and throughput, and in the early stages of a startup many of them are too expensive to implement or are simply unnecessary. When you're two ramen-fuelled developers in a basement, the right amount of process is "not much". When you're a globe-straddling mega-corporation, the right amount of process is "quite a lot". And of course, when you're starting out then "not much" is a natural default. If you're growing, then, generally the actual amount of process you have in place is going to trail the amount of process you need. I suspect the diagram above describes a large majority of successfully-growing startups. This "process lag" generally manifests in a certain degree of chaos, communication breakdowns, and dropped balls. This is often characterised as "growing pains". If you're in a role that is responsible for scaling and growing an organisation, what this means is that you're in the business of adding and refining process. Ideally, you get the red ball in the diagram above to catch up with the green ball, and then to keep up with it as your organisation goes on its journey. Knowing about good processes is something most experienced managers should not have too much trouble with. The art of it, and one that I look forward to learning, is how to roll them out at just the right pace that they are always supportive, never stifling.

name: danmoskowitz1
headline: Everyone is excited about what AI can do.
content: Everyone is excited about what AI can do. Fewer teams are honest about why their AI hasn't gone to production yet. Here is one of the clearer pattens that I've noticed. 1. Most companies aren't stuck on "does AI work?" They're stuck on "can this safely run in prod?" AI experimentation is mostly solved. The real bottleneck is everything that comes after the fancy demo: security, durability, and observability. That's the last mile where adoption stalls. 2. AI failures don't look like normal software failures. Also, the blast radius is potentially bigger. Model outages, silent hallucinations, prompt injection, general API weirdness that throws agents off. If you can't get a handle on these things, then it isn't safe to let your agentic workflow touch sensitive live data. 3. The next wave of AI value comes from infrastructure, not prompt engineering. The biggest winners in production will be teams that invest early in the tooling that makes agentic workflows secure, durable, and observable at scale. Not just better prompt chains that make great demos. ğŸ‘‡ For more thoughts on this, read the full blog post in the comments. ğŸ‘‡ Diagrid Mark Fussell Yaron Schneider Zenity Ben Kliger DataGrail Daniel Barber Kentik Avi Freedman

name: stephaniehillsphd
headline: I once had a team of engineers who were stuck in a cycle of doing things â€œthe way theyâ€™ve always been done.â€ Every idea was met with â€œthat wonâ€™t workâ€ or â€œwe donâ€™t have time.
content: I once had a team of engineers who were stuck in a cycle of doing things â€œthe way theyâ€™ve always been done.â€ Every idea was met with â€œthat wonâ€™t workâ€ or â€œwe donâ€™t have time.â€ Sound familiar? I knew something had to change. So, I took a page from Amazonâ€™s playbook. Their famous â€œTwo-Pizza Teamsâ€ ensure teams are small, agile, and empowered to innovate without bureaucracy slowing them down. I applied that conceptâ€”giving my team the autonomy, tools, and confidence to experiment. The results? Ideas that had been buried under red tape came to life. Productivity soared. Engagement increased. Most importantly, we created solutions that made a real impact. ğŸ”¥ 10 Ways to Build a CULTURE OF INNOVATION in Your Team ğŸ”¥ 1ï¸âƒ£ Empower Small, Agile Teams â€“ Keep teams small enough to be fed by two pizzas. Autonomy fuels creativity. 2ï¸âƒ£ Encourage Risk-Taking â€“ Innovation thrives where failure isnâ€™t punished but seen as a step toward success. 3ï¸âƒ£ Implement a â€˜Day 1â€™ Mindset â€“ Never get comfortable. Stay in startup mode, always challenging the status quo. 4ï¸âƒ£ Make Experimentation the Norm â€“ Have a budget for testing new ideas. Not every experiment wins, but all drive learning. 5ï¸âƒ£ Remove Bureaucracy â€“ Long approval chains kill momentum. Enable teams to act fast. 6ï¸âƒ£ Recognize and Reward Innovation â€“ Celebrate bold ideas, not just successful ones. 7ï¸âƒ£ Listen to Your Customers â€“ The best ideas come from solving real problems. Be obsessed with their needs. 8ï¸âƒ£ Lead by Example â€“ If leaders arenâ€™t innovating, teams wonâ€™t either. Model the behavior you want to see. 9ï¸âƒ£ Prioritize Speed Over Perfection â€“ Get ideas into the real world quickly. Iterate and improve based on real feedback. ğŸ”Ÿ Create Psychological Safety â€“ A culture of innovation starts with people feeling safe to speak up, take risks, and challenge norms. Innovation isnâ€™t an eventâ€”itâ€™s a habit. The best teams donâ€™t wait for inspiration; they build systems that make innovation inevitable. Which of these actions resonates most with you? â™» Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. â• Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. ğŸš€ #Innovation #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # hashtag#careerfreedom hashtag#leadershipdevelopment #cultureofinnovation

name: davekrupp
headline: I keep hearing that AI search is about to change everything.
content: I keep hearing that AI search is about to change everything. Maybe. But when I look at how younger consumers actually find products, the shift has already happened. OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT has scaled to 100M+ weekly users which of course is impressive. But most of that behaviour is task based and informational. On the other hand, TikTok has 1B+ monthly active users, and studies show roughly 40 percent of Gen Z prefer TikTok or Instagram for discovery over traditional search engines. If you work in FMCG or CPG, I think thatâ€™s the part that really matters. When someone searches â€œbest chocolateâ€ or â€œhigh protein ice creamâ€ on TikTok, they want taste tests, reactions, real people giving opinions. Not a neat AI summary. This is why I think food brands should be flooding TikTok with creator content - not for conversion but to own search inside the platform. Creator content indexes. It stacks over time. The more content you have out there, the more searchable your brand becomes in the moments that actually influence store purchases. AI search will evolve but right now social search is already driving buying decisions.

name: edward-singapore
headline: What does success in cyber defence look like?
content: What does success in cyber defence look like? Usually, it looks like nothing happened. Last year, Singaporeâ€™s telecommunications infrastructure came under a serious cyber threat. The response that followed â€” Operation Cyber Guardian â€” became the largest cyber defence operation in Singapore. I had the privilege of driving this operation at the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) , alongside my colleagues at IMDA and many others across government and industry. It was a marathon. Long nights. Parallel investigations. Careful containment. Re-checking assumptions. Making hard calls with incomplete information â€” and doing so calmly, professionally, and together. What Iâ€™m most proud of is the team of more than 100 officers who pulled this off. The CSA officers who stayed on watch, connected the dots, and quietly carried the operational burden. The Whole-of-Government partners who leaned in immediately, shared information freely, and moved as one team. The telco cyber defenders who worked shoulder to shoulder with us to find and fix the attacker. And above all, the collective trust that allowed us to act quickly â€” without friction, without ego, without noise. A few reflections that stayed with me: â€¢ Teamwork is not a slogan â€” it is a capability. â€¢ Speed in crisis comes from trust built long before the incident. â€¢ Good cyber defence is measured by outcomes, not headlines. Most people will never know this operation took place. And thatâ€™s exactly how it should be. To everyone across CSA, our Whole-of-Government partners, and industry colleagues who did the hard, unglamorous work behind the scenes â€” thank you. You reminded me that in cyber defence, no one defends alone, and quiet professionalism is often the strongest form of collective leadership. Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) IMDA The Digital and Intelligence Service (DIS) Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT) GovTech Singapore Internal Security Department

name: ybernstein
headline: In early history, one of the hallmarks of an advanced society was that it used writing to codify knowledge. Writing enabled more complex social structures and technologies to emerge, and the scalable distribution enabled by the printing press accelerated this massively.
content: In early history, one of the hallmarks of an advanced society was that it used writing to codify knowledge. Writing enabled more complex social structures and technologies to emerge, and the scalable distribution enabled by the printing press accelerated this massively. It's 2018. Do you follow an oral tradition or a written tradition? When your organisation is small and young, it is natural to share knowledge orally. After all, when there are only three of you the overheads of using formal issue tracking, written roadmaps, architectural documentation, onboarding guides seem very high when you could just have a quick chat. Just as with societies, though, as your organisation grows and becomes more complex that oral tradition quickly becomes a hindrance. Whereas the cost of propagating written knowledge is sublinear with respect to the size of an organisation and the passage of time, oral teaching is linear at best. Worse yet, oral histories are unreliable. Knowledge is lost to the vagaries of human memory, and by the departure of key personnel. Software is complex and technical. Ask any other professional in a complex technical field, from engineers to doctors to pilots, whether they would be comfortable relying on oral knowledge sharing instead of documentation, and they'll likely just stare at you as if you were mad. Writing is arguably the greatest technology humanity has ever come up with. Can you really say you work in tech if you don't use it?

name: stephaniehillsphd
headline: ğŸš€ Most people donâ€™t fail because they lack talent or drive. They fail because they hide in plain sightâ€”telling themselves they are waiting for the â€œright timeâ€.
content: ğŸš€ Most people donâ€™t fail because they lack talent or drive. They fail because they hide in plain sightâ€”telling themselves they are waiting for the â€œright timeâ€. ğŸ’¼ My first job in the corporate world, I was overwhelmed. I told myself I was playing it smartâ€”observing, waiting for the perfect time to step up. I thought if I just worked hard enough, someone would notice. But the truth? I was avoiding risk. I was playing defense in a game that only rewards offense. Have you ever done this?You know youâ€™re capable of more. Youâ€™ve got the skills, the knowledge, the driveâ€”but instead of stepping up, you hold back. âŒ You donâ€™t ask for the promotion because you donâ€™t feel â€œreadyâ€ yet. ğŸš« You donâ€™t start your business because of others' opinions. ğŸ˜Ÿ You donâ€™t put yourself out there because what if you fail? And while youâ€™re overthinking, someone elseâ€”less qualified but more confidentâ€”is taking the opportunities you keep passing up. Not because theyâ€™re better. But because they moved. âš ï¸ And hereâ€™s the realityâ€”the system is built to keep you playing small. ğŸ¢ Companies reward "team players" who donâ€™t rock the boat. ğŸŒ Society tells you to be â€œgratefulâ€ instead of ambitious. ğŸ—£ï¸ Even the people closest to you will say, â€œAre you sure? That sounds risky.â€ Theyâ€™re not trying to sabotage youâ€”but they are keeping you comfortable. And comfort is the enemy of growth. ğŸ”¥ How to Step Out & Own It ğŸ’¥ So what do you do? You take the damn shot. And hereâ€™s exactly how you do it: ğŸ†” Step 1: Change Your Identity Stop thinking of yourself as â€œwaiting for your chance.â€ Youâ€™re already the person who deserves itâ€”you just need to start acting like it. Decide who you are today. ğŸš€ If youâ€™re in a job, stop seeing yourself as an â€œemployeeâ€ and start acting like a leader before you have the title. ğŸ’° If youâ€™re in business, stop seeing yourself as â€œtrying to growâ€ and start operating like a 7-figure entrepreneur now. ğŸ“ˆ Step 2: Build Proof & Stack Small Wins Confidence doesnâ€™t come from waiting. It comes from action. Stack small wins every day. ğŸ¤ Speak up in the next meeting. ğŸ¥ Go live on social media for the first time. ğŸ’¼ Make an offer TODAY instead of tweaking your website for the 10th time. Wins compound. The more you do, the more unstoppable you become. ğŸ”¥ Step 3: Burn the Boats Stop keeping a backup plan for why youâ€™re not stepping up. Cut off your escape route. Make failure impossible. ğŸ’µ If you want the raise, schedule the meeting now. ğŸ“† If you want to launch, set a date and announce it. If you want to be seen, start showing up every single dayâ€”no excuses. ğŸ† Step 4: Get in the Right Rooms You donâ€™t rise by staying around people who reinforce your smallness. You need to be in rooms where success is normal, where people are already playing bigger. ğŸ¯ Get a mentor who has the results you want. ğŸ¤ Join masterminds or groups that challenge you. â³ Cut back time with people who talk you out of your potential. ğŸš€ Step 5: Make Power Moves Daily The fastest way to stop hiding? Make moves so big you canâ€™t go back. ğŸ“¢ Post the content. ğŸ’¬ Make the ask. ğŸ’¸ Charge what youâ€™re worth. ğŸ Launch the thing. ğŸš€ Take the leap. ğŸ¯ Because if you want to win... name: guybe
headline: Ten years ago, two major things happened in my life.
content: Ten years ago, two major things happened in my life. First, our twins, Neta and Omer, were born. Second, I started the next chapter of my career by joining #Microsoft as a CSA. After 20 years in software engineering, it turned out to be one of the most incredible roles Iâ€™ve ever had. Every single day I learned something new -working with many customers on #AI , #IoT , and cloud-native technologies, speaking on stages, and driving presales engagements and customer success. It was intense, inspiring, and deeply rewarding. Five years later, I decided to go back to what I enjoy the most: coding. I joined #Microsoft #CSE (known today as #ISE ), working alongside incredibly talented engineers on co-innovation and co-engineering with Microsoftâ€™s most strategic customers. Focusing on the domain I love most and passionate about - #AI - assembled as teams of data scientists and software engineers and partnered closely with customers to work on their most innovative and challenging projects. Today marks my 10-year anniversary at #Microsoft , in a role I truly enjoy. Iâ€™m genuinely happy to wake up every morning and work on impactful projects with the best teammates. Iâ€™d like to pause and give a special shout-out to all my mentors, managers, and colleagues who believed in me and gave me opportunities to grow, learn, balance time at work and spending time with my dear family. The list is much longer, but Iâ€™ll name a few: Edi Lahav , Assaf Jacoby , Itay Shakury , Yaron Schneider , Amir Assif , Yoav Dobrin , Shelly Landsmann , Tamir Kamara, Limor Lahiani, PhD. , Omri Mendels , Nava Vaisman Levy , Martin Peck , Laurent Ellerbach , Itye Richter , Rob Fraser , Dominik Wee , Michal Braverman-Blumenstyk A special thanks as well to Microsoft Garage, to Ady Mor-Biran and her wonderful team, for providing me with the space to express my creativity and turn ideas into reality. Hereâ€™s to another impactful 10! ğŸ¥‚

name: shivamdas040790
headline: We recently sat down with our trial users to talk about something deeper than specs, everyday life.
content: We recently sat down with our trial users to talk about something deeper than specs, everyday life. In a world where we are constantly connected, the role of the mobile device is shifting from a hardware tool to a cognitive partner. After reviewing our latest interview sessions, three clear themes emerged: 1. The Performance Paradox: Users no longer care about raw speed in a vacuum.They care about sustained performance. Can the phone handle a 2 hour gaming session or a heavy multitasking workday without the heat factor? Reliability is the new fast. 2. Camera as a Memory Tool, Not Just a Lens. We are seeing a shift from taking a photo to capturing a feeling. Users are looking for AI that doesnt just sharpen an image, but understands the lighting and emotion of the moment, something brands like OPPO are doubling down on to democratize professional grade creativity. 3. From Manual to Intuitive (The OPPO Factor). How is user behavior changing? Itâ€™s becoming more passive in the best way. Features that manage battery life intelligently are teaching users to trust their devices more. We are moving towards an invisible UI where the tech works in the background so the human can stay in the moment. The Bottom Line: The winner in 2026 isn't the device with the most features, its the one that manages heat, power and AI so seamlessly that the user forgets the tech is even there. To my fellow product folks, Whats the one feature you hv seen recently that actually changed your daily behavior, rather than just being a cool addition? #UserBehavior #ProductStrategy #OPPO #MobileInnovation #AI #Usertrial #OCPtrial

name: ybernstein
headline: The following is a lightly edited version of an email I sent my team about code review. We use git pull requests, but most of what I write applies to any form of code review, especially offline (as opposed to in-person) pre-commit review.
content: The following is a lightly edited version of an email I sent my team about code review. We use git pull requests, but most of what I write applies to any form of code review, especially offline (as opposed to in-person) pre-commit review. Being a code reviewer is a duty and a trust. When you hit â€œapproveâ€ on a pull request, you are making a declaration that you are comfortable that the code belongs in your codebase in its current form. If there is anything about the request that makes you uncomfortable (e.g. no unit tests!), you are duty-bound to raise that concern. That doesnâ€™t mean being unnecessarily nitpicky or combative, but it does mean that you shouldnâ€™t avoid raising a concern out of expediency or because you think the feedback wonâ€™t be well received. More eyes are always better, and there is precious little code that canâ€™t be improved by having another person look over it and make suggestions. As a reviewer, this is your job. For this to work, it is important that everybody also receives review feedback in a spirit of goodwill. When your reviewer comes back to you with feedback or requests for changes, they are not doing this to attack you or shame you or stand in the way of you getting your work done. They are doing it to fulfil their duty as a reviewer. If you have a problem with the way your code in being critiqued, please donâ€™t make your reviewer uncomfortable. You are welcome to come to me to discuss it, but I am likely to give them a fair bit of benefit of the doubt. Understanding that code criticism is not personal criticism forms a key part of egoless programming. I know the concept of duty is an old-fashioned one, but I think it captures the act of code reviewing perfectly. Reviewing code is not always going to be fun or convenient, but if done correctly it can be the key tool to ensuring we have a codebase that we can be proud of. Great code is everybodyâ€™s responsibility, and it can only happen if the whole team works together to uphold high standards. Here are some tips for making your code easy to review: -Descriptive titles and code descriptions. I think weâ€™re most of the way there, thanks everybody! -Small, atomic changes. This makes it much quicker and easier for a reviewer to understand (and hence get comfortable) with a change. Itâ€™s possible (and in many cases preferable) for a single PBI to generate multiple PRs. Atomic means not able to be broken down further: each PR should do a small number of self-contained things, and subsequent PRs can build on earlier ones. Git makes this pretty easy. Tip: If it takes more than a couple of sentences to describe your PR, consider whether it is truly atomic or should be broken down further. -Tests. One of the many wonderful things about tests is that they act as a form of documentation. Adding tests to your PR will make your change much easier to review. And here are some tips for being a good reviewer: -Quick turnarounds. You donâ€™t have to drop everything when a PR comes in, but donâ€™t keep the requestor hanging for any longer than necessary. -Minimise round-trips. That means getting all your feedback out in a single pass rather than making people go through multiple rounds. -Meaningful comments. If you want the requestor to change something make it clear what, and why. -Be respectful. Donâ€™t use emotive language (e.g. â€œthis is a dumb way to do itâ€) and remember that it is your job to help the requestor submit high quality code that does what they need it to do. I find the Socratic Method works pretty well to keep things respectful (e.g. â€œwhy did you do it this way?â€).
